At the same time the gospel of Matthew says that the Lord Jesus called the Father "Lord" (Matthew 11:25) and then the Spirit is called the Lord; "The Lord is the Spirit" (2 Corinthians 3:17).
A.N.W. The Spirit quotes in that connection, "And they, having heard it, lifted up their voice with one accord to God, and said, Lord" (that is, "despot"), "Lord, thou art the God who made the heaven and the earth" (Acts 4:24).
J.T. Very good. Quite so.
Rem. There is a similar reference in James 3:9: "Therewith bless we the Lord and Father".
J.T. Besides that, the word Jehovah, in the Old Testament, is sometimes translated Lord in the New. It is a question of understanding the truth and following it up, and comparing spiritual with spiritual.
Rem. To apply logical thinking to divine things is disastrous. It calls for spirituality.
J.T. That is good.
E.C.M. Would you say another word with regard to verse 44, "While Peter was yet speaking these words the Holy Spirit fell upon all those who were hearing the word". Would you regard that as being normal today?
J.T. Even if it is only once, it is there, and there is
[Page 428]
scriptural authority for it. And this may be compared with how the Spirit came in in Acts 2.
H.J.E. Is what happens in verse 44 governed by the end of verse 33, "Now therefore we are all present before God to hear all things that are commanded thee of God"?
J.T. That is quite true. Very good. And so verse 44 says, "While Peter was yet speaking these words the Holy Spirit fell upon all those who were hearing the word", showing that there is virtue attached to hearing the word. The word is logos there, the Word. "And the faithful of the circumcision were astonished, as many as came with Peter, that upon the nations also the gift of the Holy Spirit was poured out: for they heard them speaking with tongues and magnifying God". Acts 10:45. So that we are now coming to the conclusion of the subject, although in chapter 11 the question is raised again because of Jewish opposition to it; but now the positive side is in these verses. "Then Peter answered, Can any one forbid water that these should not be baptised, who have received the Holy Spirit as we also did? And he commanded them to be baptised". Acts 10:47. Peter raises the question, "Can any one forbid water that these should not be baptised?" Now, in regard of the man that Philip had spoken to, in chapter 8, water was not forbidden. He says, "Behold, water" and Philip went down with him into the water and baptised him. Here it is, Peter says, "Can any one forbid water that these should not be baptised, who have received the Holy Spirit as we also did?" But the point he makes is that if the Holy Spirit is given to a man, or a person, why should he not be baptised? He certainly should be baptised. Nobody should forbid it.
Ques. Would you refer to the Holy Spirit in the gospel preaching?
J.T. Certainly. It is referred to here; Peter is really preaching the gospel here.
W.C. Would it be right to say that the gospel is not complete if the Spirit is not brought in?
[Page 429]
J.T. I would say that, because the dispensation has to be complete, as you say, and our dispensation is really the dispensation of the Holy Spirit.
Eu.R. In a day of great profession, it would be good to raise the question: "Did ye receive the Holy Spirit when ye had believed?" (Acts 19:2).
J.T. Very good. That was Paul's question to the twelve men at Ephesus. They did not know, they said; and it is the same now; how many people are ignorant of the truth!
Ques Why were these not baptised in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit?
J.T. Because Peter is an apostle, and Peter would have authority and he commanded them to be baptised. He has the authority of Christ; he is made an apostle.
A.P.B. When they were to be baptised, Peter "commanded them to be baptised in the name of the Lord" Acts 10:48. That would not shut out their being baptised in the name of the Father, and the Son and the Holy Spirit, would it?
J.T. Not at all. If it says, baptising them in the name of the Lord, then the Lord is God. We must make allowance for God. I would myself always use Matthew 28, because it is so complete and in the assembly gospel, but both are right. If I am allowed to speak of what I do myself, I quote Matthew 28and also what Peter said here, what is done in the name of the Lord, but both are effectual, only what is done in the name of the Lord makes more of the idea of the authority of the Lord. In Matthew 28:19 it is, "To the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit", whereas here it is "in the name of the Lord".
Ques. Do you think Peter would be influenced at all by the fact that they had already received the Holy Spirit?
J.T. He certainly is influenced, because it says, "Then Peter answered, Can any one forbid water that
[Page 430]
these should not be baptised, who have received the Holy Spirit?" Acts 10:47. He was influenced by it; it was because the Holy Spirit had been given to them that he is asserting that they should be baptised.
F.J.F. And the gift of the Spirit is a pure sovereign gift of God?
J.T. Quite so; only it is based on redemption, of course, and based on faith.
Ques. Had it in view bringing Cornelius and his household into the same liberty with the Spirit which Peter himself had known?
J.T. Well, just so; if we saw that household probably we would be fully impressed by it. At the same time I should not think they had come fully into what Peter had come into; he was further on than they would be even then, I would say. But anyway, what we are dealing with now is that Peter's address to these men, to Cornelius and his house, is the gospel. It is the introduction of the gospel and christianity to the household of Cornelius and to the gentiles, and a very important point is that the gentiles are now brought into christianity.
J.T.S. Did you say that the Holy Spirit acted of Himself when He fell on all those who were hearing the word?
J.T. Certainly.
J.T.S. Would there be some thought of affectionate delight in that?
J.T. Very likely; because the Spirit is God Himself. As we have said over and over again here, the Spirit is God Himself; if the Spirit did it, God did it.
J.T.S. I was thinking of the word in Luke 15:20: "His father ... ran, and fell upon his neck", in affectionate delight.
J.T. Quite so. When we preach the gospel from that passage, we take it that the Father did it. Well, if the Father did it, the Son did it; the Son would ratify it,
[Page 431]
whatever it might be. Any One of the three Persons can act as God.
J.T.S. In Acts 2:33 it says: "Having received of the Father the promise of the Holy Spirit, he has poured out this which ye behold and hear". Now we have the Spirit falling on those who received the word.
J.T. Well, it asserts the power and the liberty that the Spirit has. It asserts too that He is a divine Person, with the same authority as the Father and the Son. We cannot insist on that too much, that He is a divine Person as the Father and the Son are divine.
W.B.H. May I just ask what might be learned from the expression, "the gift of the Holy Spirit" (Acts 2:38), and then "ye have received the Spirit" (Galatians 3:2)?
J.T. The Spirit is a gift and they received it.
[Page 432]
Pages 432 - 501 -- Ministry not published previously.
THE SERVICE OF THE HOLY SPIRIT IN THE ASSEMBLY
Acts 13:1 - 4; Acts 20:22,23; Acts 21:4; 1 Corinthians 3:16
Our subject this evening is the Holy Spirit. This subject is very comprehensive. My thought is to show how the Spirit's activity makes itself felt in the local assemblies. As we have already considered the Lord's operations, both universal and local, I think it would help now to consider the Spirit's activity.
One of the great basic truths of christianity is the presence of the Holy Spirit here personally. John presents in his gospel the truth of the Holy Spirit's presence in the saints, for their joy and help; and Luke presents the service of the Spirit as available for the furtherance of the testimony, as well as operating for the blessing of men. Only John speaks of Him as the Comforter. In general, John uses the title "the Spirit", but Luke usually says "the Holy Spirit". Luke has in view the public result of the Spirit's service, and says therefore in Acts 2:3 that the Holy Spirit "sat upon each one of them". The public vessel of testimony is in view in Luke's gospel, and is the vessel through which God, by the gospel, will speak to men. Therefore the added word "holy" is very significant in this connection, because men can very well understand that the power which is now active is a holy power, which cannot be linked with the flesh in man. It was never God's intention, when He sent the Holy Spirit, to give something to man that would exalt him. But, as I have said, John rarely uses the expression "the Holy Spirit". It is true that he says that the Lord would baptise with the Holy Spirit, but there it is in line with Luke's presentation, because this involves that the believer rejects the flesh and merges in the circle of the saints, But, as I
[Page 433]
said, John uses the title "the Spirit", both in connection with the individual believer and also when the Spirit is referred to as a divine Person amongst the saints.
The Lord speaks of the Spirit as "another Comforter". The Lord Himself has gone to heaven, and the Father has sent another Comforter to the saints, who would be with them for ever. Is it not wonderful that, just as there is One in heaven who serves as well as represents us there, a divine Person who is our Patron and takes up all our affairs there, so also is there another divine Person down here who in the same way looks after us and all our affairs here. He has been here since Pentecost in His wonderful service to the saints. It is wonderful to think that He actually has care of all the affairs of the saints and their needs. I do not say 'the assembly's needs', for John does not use that word. The scripture in question refers more to those who compose the assembly, and we, beloved brethren, who through God's grace belong to the saints, have such a Person amongst us. As such He has to do with the whole christian company on earth. There is not one among the saints on earth who is not the object of the Spirit's interest. So the Lord says that the world did not know the Spirit, "but ye know him" (John 14:17). Beloved brethren, do we know the Spirit? Sometimes we make the mistake of taking Him for another spirit, and sometimes we take another spirit for Him. We must therefore be watchful so as to recognise and to acknowledge the Spirit. As the Lord said to His disciples, "ye know him, for he abides with you and shall be in you" John 14:17. I would therefore like to ask again if we know the Spirit, this Comforter, who has come down from the Father.
He performs His service in different ways. I speak of Him now as a divine Person amongst the saints, and therefore thought to say something of His universal service, which has in view the whole assembly. To appreciate Him in this way, we must keep the unity
[Page 434]
of the Spirit. The unity of the Spirit is a universal thought. It involves that I understand His universal service. Different places may enjoy different service, but the service is one, because there is only one Spirit. The apostle says in Ephesians 4:2, "with all lowliness and meekness, with longsuffering, bearing with one another in love, using diligence to keep the unity of the Spirit in the uniting bond of peace", and then he continues to say, "one body and one Spirit". In order to keep the unity of the Spirit, we must understand what His universal service is. There are other features of this service which also apply to the whole assembly; one could name many, but one feature specially comes out in 1 Timothy 4:1, where it says that "the Spirit speaks expressly, that in latter times" (the time in which we find ourselves) "some shall apostatise from the faith, giving their mind to deceiving spirits and teachings of demons". I mention this so that we may be on the look-out for it, as the Spirit speaks of it expressly. If the Holy Spirit emphasises any special service, or any particular matter, it is in order that we should pay attention to it. What the Spirit says to the assemblies has this character. So we find the final view of the Spirit's service in the Revelation, last chapter, where the Lord speaks of His own service in the character of "the root and offspring of David, the bright and morning star" Revelation 22:16, and where He adds, "And the Spirit and the bride say, Come" Revelation 22:17. The Spirit has then won all for Christ; His service has not been without result. He has won the bride for Christ, and the bride is here in harmony with the Spirit for "The Spirit and the bride say, Come" Revelation 22:17.
Having said so much as to the Spirit's universal service, I wish also to say something as to His operations as they come to light in a particular place. The assembly in Antioch forms an introduction to our subject; the beginning was there because the local conditions in that place were suitable for the Spirit's service. The Holy
[Page 435]
Spirit was personally active, He was, I may add, there in His limitless, all-powerful activity. And so the importance of His personal rights becomes prominent because, even if He be sent to this earth, He is nevertheless a divine Person who has divine rights. Chapter 13 begins by speaking of the persons who were in the assembly in that city. Note that it says that they were in Antioch, for when the Spirit is not exercising His universal service, we find that local operations are spoken about. "Now there were in Antioch, in the assembly which was there, prophets and teachers: Barnabas, and Simeon who was called Niger, and Lucius the Cyrenian, and Manaen, foster-brother of Herod the tetrarch, and Saul" Acts 13:1. How interesting this city was to heaven at this time, not the city itself, but the people who dwelt there! We see here how God takes note of cities, towns and villages, but especially cities. In another place we find, for example, that elders should be established in each city (Titus 1:5). No matter what government may be found in a city, God regards that city in the light of His testimony in that place. Therefore it says of the believers in Corinth that they were "the assembly of God which is in Corinth", and they are called "Corinthians" (2 Corinthians 6:11). We have thus a special responsibility to fulfil in the place where we live. The Spirit operates in a certain place and wants order there, and every one of the saints in that place must recognise and acknowledge that as they take their place amongst the people of God there.
In Acts 13:1 the names are given of the persons whom the Spirit specially marked out in Antioch, and it says that they ministered to the Lord and fasted. While the principle of mutuality and uniformity exists in the assembly of God on earth, we see nevertheless that some have a special place, and such are named here, those whom the Holy Spirit especially marked out. Such saints give character to the place where they live, and we do well to pay attention to those whom the Spirit
[Page 436]
of God marks out, those who speak the word of God to us and minister to the Lord and fast. They ought to be greatly valued and their voice listened to by us.
Accordingly we find in this scripture a wonderful chain of circumstances which open the way for the Holy Spirit to operate amongst the saints freely and without limit. Therefore He says, "Separate me now Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them. Then, having fasted and prayed, and having laid their hands on them" (that is to say, the saints thereby expressed their confidence in Saul and Barnabas), "they let them go" Acts 13:2,3. Thereafter it says that they were "sent forth by the Holy Spirit" Acts 13:4. Yes, dear brethren, it is when we in a place acknowledge the principles of the Spirit that He can do great things for us. We will find that a gift is constantly on the move, because a gift is not restricted to (placed in) a certain place, but is for the assembly as a whole.
In chapter 20 the apostle says that he went to Jerusalem bound in spirit. It was very serious for him to go there and at the same time be bound in his spirit. It is not becoming for us to criticise the great apostle, as we could find ourselves in a similar position where our spirit was bound and the way not clear for us. "And now, behold, bound in my spirit, I go to Jerusalem, not knowing what things shall happen to me in it; only that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city, saying that bonds and tribulations await me" Acts 20:22,23. I desire that we might pay attention to this, as every word in this scripture has a meaning. The apostle could have said, 'the Holy Spirit testifies and says that bonds await me', but he says, "only that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city". We see in this the great profit in having local assemblies which are subject to the Lord and ready for the service of the Spirit, because this testimony came through the saints who lived in those cities. This clearly follows from chapter 21:4, where the disciples spoke to him "by the Spirit". How
[Page 437]
wonderful that the Holy Spirit was available in this way to the saints, and that they could speak thus to Paul concerning his ministry! It was as anointed by the Spirit that the Lord began His wonderful ministry, and I would bring this home to the young who take part in the service of the assembly that they might specially think of speaking by the Spirit. David said, "The Spirit of Jehovah spoke by me, and his word was on my tongue" 2 Samuel 23:2. The Holy Spirit is available to us. He is, so to speak, at our disposal, and we are therefore not thrown upon our own capability and competence. May we learn to make use of the Spirit when we serve the saints!
In chapter 13 we saw that the Spirit was active as a divine Person, and in chapter 20 He 'testified and said' to Paul, but in chapter 21 He speaks through the disciples. When the Holy Spirit speaks to us, He speaks through the saints. He did not become man like the Lord Jesus, but it says, "it sat upon each one of them" (Acts 2:3). "And they were all filled with the Holy Spirit, and began to speak with other tongues as the Spirit gave to them to speak forth". The voice of the Spirit comes to us therefore through the saints.
In 1 Corinthians 3:16 we have presented to us the temple in its local character. This has the greatest meaning for us in the place where we live, and in our own circle, It says, "Do ye not know that ye are (the) temple of God, and that the Spirit of God dwells in you?" When the apostle says "ye", he means the saints who dwelt in Corinth, but when he uses the word "we" he means all the saints. Here he speaks to the local company which was in Corinth. They were God's temple, and it is a question of their character. It says, "ye are God's temple", which involves what the character of the company is as having the Spirit of God. The saints are "temple of God". We do not get the thought of several temples of God either. The Corinthians had, so to speak, temple character.
[Page 438]
Every local assembly has therefore the privilege to be marked by this, and the consequences will be that we will be independent of man's natural gifts. The Corinthians were familiar with the thought of the temple. How great it is to have the character of being God's temple! It is in the light of this that we can sit down and read the Scriptures together, for, when we do this as really subject to the Lord, we then get light and have God's thoughts about everything.
We all remember how Joshua, in connection with the children of Israel, on a certain occasion did not ask counsel of the Lord, and how they were thus deceived by the Gibeonites (Joshua 9). Every local company of the assembly should be the temple of God in character. The psalmist says, "One thing have I asked of Jehovah, that will I seek after: that I may dwell in the house of Jehovah all the days of my life, to behold the beauty of Jehovah, and to inquire of him in his temple" (Psalm 27:4). We see here how the psalmist makes a difference between "house" and "temple". The temple is a place where one can enquire of God. We know from David's history how he enquired of the Lord. Saul also tried to enquire of the Lord, but he was not in a right state. David enquired, and the Lord answered him through the Urim. We thus experience the wonderful way in which God sees to all our needs in the place where we live. We can enquire in His temple, and if we in humility seek to know His will, we shall never be disappointed. The answer we need can come as the result of the exercises of a spiritual brother or a spiritual sister. The Lord knows the answer to give us and, by the Spirit who dwells in us, God has a way of doing this. God can in this way make known to us His will. The apostle says, "we have the mind of Christ" (1 Corinthians 2:16); that is to say, we possess the ability to distinguish spiritually in a way which corresponds to Christ. The Lord can thus make known His will, both for us and through us.
[Page 439]
THE FELLOWSHIP OF THE SPIRIT
Philippians 2:1,2; 1 John 5:6 (last clause),7
J.T. Here in Philippians we have the fellowship of the Spirit mentioned, and it was known at Philippi. I think that in dealing with the subject of fellowship, and, having reference to the fellowship of the Spirit, it would be a help to link it with the spirit of control. The witness of the Spirit is connected with rule: the spirit of control. In the gospel of John He is spoken of as the Spirit of truth. It will be observed it is not fellowship with the Spirit, but fellowship of the Spirit. The kind of thing the fellowship is may be considered under three heads -- the fellowship of God's Son, the fellowship of the death of Christ, and then as in Philippians the fellowship of the Spirit. John's epistle deals with fellowship with one another, but the character of the thing is what is presented in the letter to the Corinthians and here too in the epistle to the Philippians.
Ques. Would you mind explaining exactly what you mean by the Spirit? Is it origin or character?
J.T. He is a divine Person giving character in that way. We are in that kind of fellowship. You get a wonderful balance in the three things which characterise it. 1 Corinthians alludes to the dignity of it, the fellowship of God's Son, Jesus Christ our Lord; the fellowship of His death in chapter 10 cuts us off from the world, and the fellowship of the Spirit in Philippians brings in what is positive, and what we may say is subjective. We are kept not only by the Scriptures, but by the Spirit of truth; the Spirit of truth controls in a subjective way.
What comes out in John 14, 15 and 16 is the Comforter. "If ye love me, keep my commandments" John 14:15. "He shall give you another Comforter ... even the Spirit of truth; whom the world cannot receive because it seeth him not, neither knoweth him: but ye know
[Page 440]
him; for he dwelleth with you and shall be in you" John 14:16,17. We are marked off from the world at once, by the presence of One whom the world cannot see nor know; we are marked off in a positive way by the presence of the Comforter -- a divine Person here whom the world cannot see nor know.
Ques. "Thinking the same thing" Philippians 2:2, is that the evidence of the fellowship of the Spirit?
J.T. It is the effect of the unity. We see in John how those are marked off from the world. It is said that the Father would send the Spirit in Christ's name, so that, as here, He would teach them all things and bring to remembrance the things that Jesus said. We have the Teacher and as One who teaches all things and brings to remembrance the things that Jesus said; He brings in the whole value of the ministry of Christ. And then it goes on to say in chapter 15 that the Lord would send Him in order that He should witness of Him. As having been with the Father, He knows what the Father thinks about the Son. It is put that way on our account, that we might know that in the witness of the Spirit here, we have the evidence of what the Father thinks about Christ. The Son sends Him as from being with the Father, as it reads. Thus we have a further thing: He will not only bring all things to the remembrance of the twelve; but He would bring in more, He would bring in in His witness, what the Father thinks about Christ.
Ques. Would that be set forth in type in Abraham's servant when he went to seek a bride for Isaac? He opened the treasures of silver and gold and raiment, which all came from the father's hand.
J.T. Yes, that is the thought; they were the witness of what Abraham had in mind for the ornamentation of Rebekah and of the wealth he possessed. All that Abraham had he gave to Isaac.
Rem. I think you said that the Spirit's work was to bring Christ objectively before our hearts, as set forth
[Page 441]
in the jewels of silver and gold, and that the raiment was subjective work.
J.T. Quite. And the servant knew the place that Isaac had in Abraham's affections, "thy son, thine only son, whom thou lovest, Isaac" Genesis 22:2. He was not only the messenger, but went qualified as knowing Abraham, to convey to Rebekah what the father thought of Isaac.
Ques. Is your thought that as we enter by the Spirit into what the Father thinks of the Son and all that which is set forth in Him, so we come into these things, and then there is fellowship, there is a partnership in it?
J.T. Yes. You get an apprehension in John of what the Spirit is, what His function is, and what He goes on with, and thus you see the greatness of what you are brought into. You have a great deal in the fact that it is the fellowship of God's Son, but then there is a divine Person here actually going on with us, positively, every day, and we have part in that.
Rem. That is why, if I am not in the fellowship of His death, I am finding my pleasure in things on the wrong side, and it would be an interruption of the fellowship.
J.T. That is right. The fellowship of His death cuts us off from the world. You can see what wonderful things the Holy Spirit is going on with, so that the fellowship is not only governed by Scripture and is authoritative, but by that which is subjective -- the feelings and affections being with you in truth. Many things could be among us, but the Spirit of truth enables us to see everything, so that it is not only that we have the Scriptures, but there is the fellowship that was set up and existed before we had the New Testament Scriptures.
Ques. It would raise a question as to whether we receive communications of the Spirit.
J.T. I think it does. The word is "He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the
[Page 442]
churches" Revelation 2:7. The Holy Spirit speaks to the churches, and he that has an ear hears what He says. There are communications.
Rem. We have not only the Scriptures, but spiritual sensibilities.
J.T. We have the spirit of truth, so that things commend themselves to us; what is not true does not commend itself. You might not be able to give the reason exactly, but you are conscious that it is not true. John speaks of the spirit of truth and the spirit of error. It is not only that we have the Scriptures, but there is the spirit of things -- the spirit of truth and the spirit of error.
Ques. Would the apostle give the Spirit a great place? "The Spirit searcheth all things, even the depths of God" 1 Corinthians 2:10.
J.T. That is set over against the wisdom of man.
Ques. What practical effect would this have upon us?
J.T. We would have part in what the Holy Spirit is going on with, and that is a very great thing.
Rem. It is suggestive of what we enjoy together.
J.T. Quite. You see what He is doing. In the Acts chapter 2 we see the coming in of what is in view. First of all they were all together, for all the saints are needed; no one is non-essential. They were all together in one place. They were all there, as if each felt that each should be there. We are thus reminded of the importance of being together; for as the saints come together in assembly, there should be the sense that no one should be absent; that each is essential for what God has in mind. And then it says, "There came a sound from heaven ... and it filled all the house" Acts 2:2; a distinct sound over against what is going on around, and it fills the house, And then there appeared to them "cloven tongues like as of fire" Acts 2:3. We see before us what God has in His mind. "Cloven tongues like as of fire, and it sat upon each of them" Acts 2:3; so that one would say in the light of all that, one's tongue is to be employed
[Page 443]
in it. Those people who were there were to have part in it all. "Parted tongues, as of fire" Acts 2:3, suggest that the communications that go forth should be free from all corruption and taint. I cannot allow a tainted course and words, because the fire is intended to purify. You are to have part in one Spirit; one sound filled all the house where they were sitting; and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit, and they began to speak with other tongues, showing that they understood they were to have part in this thing. It is not simply that they were to be ornamented with tongues of fire; that is what they saw, but that they should understand what it meant and that they were to have part in it, "They began to speak with other tongues as the Spirit gave to them to speak forth" Acts 2:4.
Ques. Were there special conditions there that it could be said of them, that the Holy Spirit came upon each of them?
J.T. "It sat", we read; there were conditions there which the Spirit could take up a permanent position. God has committed Himself in the giving of the Spirit in view of His testimony. "It sat upon each of them". Acts 2:3. They saw, and then they were all filled with the Holy Spirit -- and the immediate result in them was they began to speak forth.
Ques. What is the extent of the fellowship of the Spirit today?
J.T. We want to understand limitations, and it is our duty to bow to such.
Ques. Could it be said of christians at the present moment that the Spirit sat on them?
J.T. What they saw on the day of Pentecost was a sign. We do not have signs now. The thing is to get the divine idea and that remains. There was no repetition of that, although in Acts 10the Holy Spirit fell upon all those that heard the word. The divine thought is generously declared. I referred to chapter 2 as a great general principle. There was not only the sound, but
[Page 444]
what they saw, and what they did. They were given the Spirit and then they began to speak forth. That is the general view-point at the outset, and the testimony was that the multitude heard them speak in their own language the wonderful works of God. You have in these few verses of Acts 2the divine thought as to the coming in of the Spirit. There is no withdrawal of the Spirit; the idea is that He sat. Now in the Lord's case, He came down as a dove, bodily, without any accompanying things -- no idea of fire, because there was nothing to deal with in the blessed Lord; but in the coming in at Pentecost, He is in the character of parted tongues of fire sitting upon each, meaning that He would deal with all that was contrary in each, and that the tongue should not be partial, nor national; they should be ready to be employed by the Spirit universally.
Rem. With reference to Haggai, there was recovery. The Lord recalls them. "My spirit remaineth among you". Haggai 2:5. The power was there.
J.T. In Nehemiah, after recovery, the prophets of God helped to build. Now Haggai says, the covenant remains unchangeable. But then what about the power to make it good? So he says, "My spirit remaineth among you" Haggai 2:5. In Zechariah 4we have a further thought of a man who was woken out of sleep, which, I think, points to recovery because there had been a general slumber. When he waked out of sleep, he saw the symbol of the Spirit in the olive tree; and the word is "Not by might, nor by power, but by my spirit, saith the Lord" Zechariah 4:6. We have come to the day of very small things, but the hand that laid the foundation would lay the top-stone. The Holy Spirit is aiming at the top-stone of the building, and that is a very fine piece of work.
So that we want to see what He goes on with, and to hear what the Spirit says to the churches. The headstone is connected with the Lord's supper, because in
[Page 445]
Ephesians it is said "Jesus Christ himself being the chief corner stone" Ephesians 2:20. It is Jesus Christ Himself, and I think that John's ministry is to emphasise that. The Lord's supper in Luke is a memorial. It is "Jesus himself stood in the midst" Luke 24:36, while they were speaking. They were saying "The Lord is risen indeed, and has appeared unto Simon" Luke 24:34, that is, they were speaking with the utmost confidence; they had no doubt about what they are saying: "and he has appeared unto Simon". There is a sense of grace in what they say, for Simon was the one who had denied Him, The Lord was recognised and had been made known to the two going to Emmaus, in the breaking of bread. The assembly of God is not a debating society, it is a place of positive things; that is Luke's side. They were saying these things, and as they were saying them, Jesus Himself stood in the midst. I think the assembly is a place where brethren speak with intelligence, and the Lord comes in on those lines: "As they said these things, Jesus himself stood in the midst" Luke 24:36. John in order to bring the thing in positively that the Lord Himself is doing things in the last days, makes nothing of service. The twelve are mentioned but it is said that one of them was a devil. So that I think the Lord is showing us that He is doing things for us in His love, and the top-stone, it seems to me, is coming into view, We thus see the place the Lord has, and the place that the Holy Spirit gives Him.
Rem. "The Spirit and the bride say, Come". Revelation 22:17.
J.T. It is His doing -- "I Jesus" Revelation 22:16. The Lord is everything. "I am the root and offspring of David". Revelation 22:16. "Before Abraham was, I am". John 8:58. He was before Abraham. The church understands that. Matthew's gospel is that He is first.
Rem. The whole of the present revival is the exaltation of Christ by the Spirit in the minds of the saints.
J.T. In that way I think the assembly reaches heavenly conditions. The Spirit of God would lead in that direction, that there should be a company here
[Page 446]
where heavenly conditions are reached, and where Christ is everything. The place the Lord's supper has had is undoubtedly the work of the Spirit in the saints. It brings into view "Jesus Himself".
The communication of the Spirit at Philippi is very special in view of limitation. The apostle wanted to visit the province of Asia but the Holy Spirit says to him, Do not preach in Asia. There you see the beginning of divine limitations; He was limiting Paul; He was directing him to a certain part of the field; so He was limiting him. They essayed to go to Bithynia but "the Spirit suffered them not" Acts 16:7. We have to learn, therefore, the principle of limitation, not only governmental limitations, but direct limitations by the Spirit. The Spirit limited Paul on this occasion. It may be said the command was, "Go into all the world, and preach the glad tidings to all the creation" Mark 16:15, but while we hold that, we must never forger we have to get our orders. The mind of God is that the gospel should be preached to all creation, but the preachers are not to do as they please; they are under the Lord, under the Spirit. As it says, "Separate me now Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them" Acts 13:2. The Spirit of God restricts them.
Ques. Why do you think they were forbidden to preach in Asia?
J.T. It brings in the principle of limitation. Of course he did preach in Asia later, It raises another question as to why Africa and why Asia with their millions are still in darkness. It all comes under the head of divine limitations, that is to say, the Lord has the control.
Ques. Why is it that with Philip the Lord directs him first and then the Spirit says, "Join thyself to this chariot"? Acts 8:29.
J.T. In Acts 8:26 an angel is directing Philip, that is to say, it is God's providential way. The Lord knows better than I do where the soil is, so that I have to seek His guidance.
[Page 447]
What is He going on with at the end of the period? You do not want to miss that. The field is His and the labourers have to come to it. When the Eastern world comes into blessing they will come up to Jerusalem. That was the sign at the very outset for the wise men came from the East to worship Him. What has happened is that God has come out to the West and taken the assembly out of that. The unfoldings of the Spirit are wonderful. He comes forth from with the Father, which conveys the idea that He is with the Father, and thus is competent to unfold all the Father's feelings, and affections, and counsels in regard to the Son. And, oh, what depths! As it says, "The Spirit searcheth all things, even the depths of God" 1 Corinthians 2:10.
[Page 448]
THE PRACTICAL ANSWER TO THE SPIRIT AS THE TRUTH
John 16:13,14; John 8:31,32; Luke 1:1 - 4; Numbers 15:32 - 36
I was thinking, dear brethren, of the Spirit of truth. The Lord Jesus is said to be "the truth" objectively; He says, "I am ... the truth" (John 14:6) and the Spirit also is said to be "the truth" (1 John 5:6) as I may say in a subjective sense, in order that there should be correspondence here in the saints with Christ, while He is away; therefore the Spirit, as here, is said to be "the truth". The Spirit is also "the Spirit of truth" (John 14:17), conveying what is spiritual in regard of the truth, and He enters into it in all its parts as worked out in the saints, so that what is amongst us is not merely verbal doctrine, but is quick and powerful with the Holy Spirit; He makes it living. So that it is altogether different from what scientific men may have from investigation. By investigation of the creation they obtain certain facts, but they are merely that; they are devoid of the Spirit, of the fulness and sap which the Holy Spirit would impart; but He is not here to unfold to us the creation. He could, of course, unfold a depth of knowledge entering into the physical system that is around us, but that is not His mission; He is here in regard of the truth in its hearing on men as it is unfolded, as I said, objectively in Christ; and He gives it power and pungency and buoyancy that cannot be found in ordinary science so-called. Scientific men have not stopped at investigating the handiwork of God; they have attempted to investigate Himself, and have intruded into things which they have not seen, and laid unholy hands on divine Persons, evolving a system covered by a scientific name, as such words go, called theology. What was evolved of necessity had to fit in with human thoughts and conceptions,
[Page 449]
and they laboured apart from faith; not that one is accusing anyone, or denying that beloved children of God were engaged in it, but the whole principle is that of science so-called, and therefore it is not the Spirit of truth. Without the Spirit of truth we cannot have the truth according to God, however clear the letter may seem to be. Divine things, and especially divine Persons, must be treated of on the principle of faith, and by the Spirit of God; "for what man knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit of man which is in him? even so the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God. Now we have received, not the spirit of the world, but the spirit which is of God; that we might know the things that are freely given to us of God" (1 Corinthians 2:11 - 12); and, in verse 10, "the Spirit searcheth all things, yea, the deep things of God". Even as regards material things a true apprehension of them is on the principle of faith, for it is "by faith we apprehend that the worlds were framed by the word of God" (Hebrews 11:3).
So, dear brethren, what opens up to us, is that the Spirit of truth is come. It is not simply an historical fact; it is an abiding fact. It is historical, but the point is that He is come, He is here, and He is here abidingly. He is here to guide us into all the truth, and to show us things to come. It is one of the most stupendous facts that can be stated, and bears on every true christian at this time that he may be freed from the error that is current. We are living in days marked peculiarly by error, and hence John's ministry emboldens us and renders us independent of and superior to the pretensions of man's mind at the present moment. John in his first epistle tells even the little children, "ye have the unction from the holy one, and ye know all things" (1 John 2:20). No scientific man can presume to that.
So we have this remarkable statement by the Lord Himself: "when he is come, the Spirit of truth, he shall guide you into all the truth: for he shall not speak from
[Page 450]
himself; but whatsoever he shall hear he shall speak; and he will announce to you what is coming. He shall glorify me, for he shall receive of mine and shall announce it to you" (John 16:13, 14). That is the great general position, dear brethren, which enters into this meeting, as it does into all such meetings: the Spirit of truth being here is available to open up things and to show us things -- the things of Christ. Over against that, as I said, is the working of error, of which the apostle warns the young Thessalonian christians; he says, speaking of some, that "because they received not the love of the truth, that they might be saved ... God shall send them strong delusion" (2 Thessalonians 2:10,11). There is a moral reason for this for they "believed not the truth" (verse 12); but the apostle speaks to the Thessalonians as chosen through "sanctification of the Spirit and belief of the truth" 2 Thessalonians 2:13. It speaks of that kind of belief, that lies in the sanctification of the Spirit, not merely what is acquired by earnest study, right enough as meditation and study are; but the belief of the truth which holds us and stands us in good stead against error is that which goes with the "sanctification of the Spirit and belief of the truth". So that the love of it is there; it is received, and believed in sanctification; it is held in holiness. As Peter says, "we have believed and known that thou art the holy one of God" (John 6:69). In no sense is holiness so imperative as in regard to the reception of the truth, for our minds are so treacherous, and we are so capable of receiving it mentally, that it becomes unholy; it becomes mixed with human thoughts. It is in the sanctification of the Spirit that belief of the truth has its true place.
So I read in John 8in order that we might see that not only is the truth unfolded by the Spirit, but that it may be accepted in a spurious manner, and not really received in the love of it or believed in through sanctification of the Spirit. The Lord has in mind that not only shall the truth be unfolded, and even
[Page 451]
shown, but that it should be known: "Ye shall know the truth" He says. This leads me to remark on how things are among the people of God, and how they should be, and how the Lord intended them to be. He intended that amongst His people there should be knowledge of the truth, such as I have been speaking of, so that His people should never have to ask, "What is truth?" that they should never be under the influence and power of laxity or indifference, but that the truth should be known amongst them, even though it may not be known in its fulness, for we only know in part, but that the truth should be known in principle where the Holy Spirit is, that there should be spiritual capability, a most important matter, for we have the instincts and the power which render us capable of knowing it. It is thus, in principle, that the truth as a whole is known. In virtue of the Spirit being "the truth" and "the Spirit of truth" there is that here, which, at least in principle, answers to the truth as presented in Christ. That is to say, the fruit and result of the epistles, and of the ministry of the apostle, correspond to the gospels. The gospels were intended to confirm the result of the ministry, showing that the ministry was such as it was designed to be, that the saints were left with the knowledge of the truth; they had it in their possession, The apostles under God left the truth among the saints; and that, as I said, is what John's ministry largely sets out. So this word of the Lord's is cited by John as being spoken to certain of the Jews which believed on Him. They had heard the wonderful unfolding recorded in this chapter. One of the most marvellous parts of Scripture is the eighth chapter of John. They had heard what He was saying, and many of them believed on Him. He said to those who believed on Him: "If ye continue in my word, then are ye my disciples indeed; and ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free" John 8:31,32. You see, dear brethren, how another phase comes in here. "If ye continue in my word ... ye
[Page 452]
shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free" John 8:31,32. It has to be admitted lamentably, that almost immediately after the wonderful ministry of the Spirit through the apostles, this verse was neglected; there was not the continuance in the word of Christ. It was the continuance in the word of Christ which would have saved the brethren, the early disciples, from that system of doctrine of which I have spoken; they would have known the truth, and the truth would have made them free; but instead of that a way was opened for men's minds; so we have theological christianity. It is not that the Holy Spirit has been wholly out of it, or we should not be here today; the Holy Spirit has graciously been with the assembly all the time right down to the present moment, and has made the most of what there was, and has brought about a wonderful recovery for us. But, dear brethren, there was the intrusion of man's mind, and consequently we have the spurious christianity that is current, and which has been so for centuries. Now the Lord would call us out of it and bring us back (if we have not been brought back) to the fact of the Spirit of truth; and as continuing in the word of Christ we know it. It is no question of saying that I think this and another thinks that; but we know the truth; "Ye shall know the truth" says the Lord, "and the truth shall make you free" John 8:32.
Then another thing that comes up in this respect is that the ministers that God has fitted to serve His people are obligated to see to it that believers, as they come into the faith, know the truth; it is their business. There is, of course, evangelical service, and Luke represents that; he it is of all the others that presents Christ evangelically; but his great concern was that Theophilus -- representative, as I may say, of new converts, young believers -- should be sure about things; and so he says that the things about which he is about to write are matters "fully believed among us" Luke 1:1. They are not matters of question. It is not a tentative
[Page 453]
situation; there is a system of truth unfolded among us which is "fully believed". What does he allude to? He alludes, beloved, to the ministry of the apostles and how it was believed -- They are "matters fully believed among us". They are unquestionably true, and the Lord would lead us to that; that it is possible for the saints of God in dependence on the Holy Spirit, to arrive at the truth, that it is verily the truth, although it may not have been so regarded hitherto, it is now proved to be the truth. Is that not possible? If not, the whole position of the assembly here is untenable. Unless the truth can be determined, the position of the assembly is untenable. But it is possible. In the presence of the truth here, in the presence of the Holy Spirit, it is possible, and imperative, too, that the truth should be arrived at, so that we can say that it is "fully believed among us"; it is incontestably the truth. Not that the Spirit of God would not make it more fully known; He would, and does so constantly; but young believers require to be brought into these things, to be accustomed to them, and to be certain about them. Many are not; even as to the enjoyment of salvation there is great uncertainty and mixed feelings; and consequently there is poverty in testimony, and poverty in praise, and indefiniteness in the service of God. So that Luke's concern here is to make Theophilus certain. That is a most important matter, and every minister of Christ should take it to heart that the saints are to be assured, and assured of everything that is confirmed by the Spirit of God among us -- that it "is truth, and is no lie" (1 John 2:27). "That thou mightest know the certainty of those things in which thou hast been instructed" Luke 1:4. Let the young christians here take these things to heart particularly. Thank God if we have been instructed in any little way! But then we want to be sure about things and confirmed in them; and the word that enters into it pointedly says, "Think of what I say, for the Lord will give thee understanding
[Page 454]
in all things" (2 Timothy 2:7). You see how impregnably we are fortified against the onrush of error -- the working of error which is coming. We may be perfectly sure of things. "Ye have an unction from the Holy One, and ye know all things", and further "ye need not that any man teach you" (1 John 2:20, 27). So that we are entirely independent of man; he can only darken us. Nothing illuminates really, but what is by the Spirit of God.
Now, I wanted to show from the passage in the Old Testament how all this really works. It is a simple record of a man doing a certain thing during the period of Israel's sojourn in the wilderness. The position in the wilderness was peculiarly open. Although a goodly number went out of Egypt, and were cared for by God like a flock by the hand of Moses and Aaron in the wilderness, yet things were open, and any Israelite could be conversant with what occurred daily. They were not scattered abroad through the world; they were compacted together in the wilderness, as I may say, around the tabernacle. Things were open, so that any ordinary Israelite could be conversant with things that happened. That reminds us of the importance of keeping our ears open to hear what is current, and what are current happenings, and that we should not be indifferent as to them. Anything that concerns Christ or the testimony should be my concern, whether it happen here or the other side of the globe; it is all one thing; the testimony is one; it is outside of nationality. There is, as Scripture says, "one body, and one Spirit ... one Lord, one faith, one baptism, one God and Father of all" (Ephesians 4:4 - 6). It is all one thing, and the divine thought is that we should be conversant with what is current, with what refers to Christ. For instance, the Lord says to the disciples at Caesarea-Philippi, "Who do men say that I the Son of man am?" (Matthew 16:13). Now they were supposed to be conversant with what men were saying about Jesus: they
[Page 455]
could tell the Lord what men were saying about Him. But then He says: "Who do ye say that I am?" It is not 'what do you think' but 'what do you say?'. In other words, What am I saying about Jesus? When I refer to His peerless Person, what do I say? May the Lord challenge us now as to what we are saying as to Jesus. If anyone is saying anything derogatory about the Lord, is that not a matter of my concern? It is: and, moreover, I should be able to tell the truth; having the Holy Spirit I should be able to say something about Jesus that counteracts the current derogatory things that are being said about Him. It is the business of every saint to guard the Person of the Lord Jesus, and that is seen in what we say about Him.
This event recorded in Numbers 15was easily seen. Everyone in the camp might have seen this action. A certain man gathered sticks on the sabbath day. Indifferent people would say, 'Sticks are useful to make a fire', That is very often how the thing is neutralised by indifferent people; they bring in something that is certainly true, but which weakens other things that are also true, and have to be provided for. It is half the truth that is so dangerous and deceptive, and is usually advocated by persons who are indifferent. We want all the truth, dear brethren; and the types indicate that the truth has many parts. The idea of parts, or sections, is very prominent in the types, especially in Exodus; and one part may be set aside unless the saints are vigilant, for in the setting aside of it certain things may be brought forward to hide the error and shield it, but vigilance for all the parts or features of the truth will save the truth.
So it might be said that sticks are useful. Surely! A great servant, Paul, as we all know, gathered sticks and made excellent use of them. How easily that might be advocated to set aside something else. He gathered sticks into a bundle and made a fire, and made heat with them. It was an act of love, an intelligent act,
[Page 456]
though outwardly insignificant. It brought out the enemy, a viper, but it does no harm. I may say that an act of love is pretty sure to arouse the enemy. "We can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth" (2 Corinthians 13:8). But here a man is gathering sticks on the sabbath day. Now to neutralise this and make little of it, one might say that, only a little while before, the sabbath had been disregarded, for some went out to gather manna on the sabbath day, and no one was put to death. You see, dear brethren, how the truth may be neutralised unless you are watchful; and so this man might have gone free. According to Exodus 16indeed it is true that they went out to gather manna, but there was none to gather! God saved them from the worst feature of error; and that was a time when God was acting in pure grace. But when we have a specific unfolding of a truth, when it is established, when it is "fully believed among us", when it is recovered territory, it is another matter altogether. If anyone attempts to disregard it or set it aside it is an offence, it is sedition, and has to be met with all the power that the Spirit of God affords to the people of God.
Now the sabbath existed in the mind of God from Genesis 2; according to the record it was there in the mind of God. It had been broken in upon and God had worked, but it was there; God ordained it; but it was not yet named. It was not called the sabbath in Genesis 2; the first mention of it formally is in Exodus 16, the connection as typified by the manna being the presence of our Lord Jesus Christ as Man here on earth. How could there really be a sabbath for God without that? The manna represents Christ as Man here, and how delightful He was to God! The Holy Spirit came down in a bodily form and abode upon Him, and the voice from heaven said, "Thou art my beloved Son; in thee I am well pleased" (Luke 3:22). Think of the delight of God in that which the manna typifies! Now some went out to gather it on the sabbath contrary to the
[Page 457]
order; but nothing was done, no one was put to death. It was the time of pure grace. But in Exodus 31we have a formal direction by Jehovah to Moses that they must keep His sabbaths. He had been unfolding to Moses on the mountain in a most wonderful way the glory of Christ as Man. How God is delighted with all that! Was it a dry service? No, beloved, it was a delightful service to God to unfold the glories of Christ, for that is what the tabernacle meant. It was in typical language, to be sure, but what was behind the language was God's perfect knowledge, anticipatively, of Christ as Man, and His perfect delight, anticipatively, in Christ as Man. And then, after introducing the pattern and the features of the tabernacle, and then the workers by whom it was to be made in its parts and set up, Jehovah enjoins upon Israel to keep His sabbaths. I ask you, dear brethren, to look at the passage at your leisure, and see how the idea of the sabbath is stressed; and not only the sabbath, but the sabbaths, for I suppose the idea in the mind of God extended beyond Christ personally to His own, to all that is of Christ; for He rests in His love, and His love is resting on Christ and the saints. Indeed, if any of you wish to examine the facts relative to the sabbath, as to its application to the people and the land, you may be surprised to find that in fifty years nearly a third of the time would be occupied with sabbath. Is there nothing in that? Indeed there is; for it means that God would have His people for Himself, absorbed with all that is presented to them in Christ, and receiving from them the due answer. That is the idea, and therefore you can see that this action was not merely a transgression of the law, it was an open challenge to God. It was a setting aside of what was so delightful to Him, something relative to Christ. It was open defiance in the sight of all Israel, in spite of all God's special desire and commandment.
So that, dear brethren, you see how all that I have been speaking of becomes nullified by a seditious,
[Page 458]
open action against the truth. We cannot allow that. They did not understand just what to do, as is often the case. The man was brought before Moses and the elders and all the congregation, and they carefully put him in ward. Thank God for that genuine, universal feeling about it! How pleased God was with that! It was a question of judging what was due to God, and whether God's word should stand, or whether a man should thus defiantly transgress.
Well, dear brethren, that is what I had in my mind, and I would urge upon us all the importance of the sabbath, and that it should not be interfered with in lawlessness, nor set aside; that nothing that refers to Christ, that opens up His glory to us, or that refers to the assembly, or God's glory in it, should be allowed to be interfered with. God has given to His people a means of dealing with all those things, so that there is a specific word here as to what should be done. The man was to be stoned, not merely by Moses, or by Moses' direction, but by all the congregation. That is what God looks for. If He graciously unfolds things to us, He looks for universal sympathy from His people, and He looks for action corresponding with the sympathy. He looks for His people to act against what interferes with His will, and with established truth as amongst His people. That is what I had, beloved brethren, to commit to you.
[Page 459]
THE SPIRIT'S FUNCTION IN THE ASSEMBLY AS CONVENED
Romans 5:5; Romans 8:14,15; Ephesians 2:18
J.T. Some of us have been occupied with some scriptures in 2 Samuel, and we concluded that we have antitypically in that book the great features of the assembly. We have in it the thought of changing over from one great feature of Christ to another, on the principle of "from glory to glory" (@ 2Corinthians 3: 18). These great features, first of all presented to us as light in the instruction we have as to the assembly, can only be experienced here by the Spirit. It has been remarked that the disciples scarcely understood anything the Lord said in His instructions while He was with them; it is doubtful whether they understood anything properly. It is by the Spirit that we understand. We are taught that no one knows "the things of a man, save the spirit of man which is in him ... even so the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God" (1 Corinthians 2:11). So that however much light we have as to the assembly, it will not become practical and workable apart from the Spirit and the place given to Him. We have in the section in 2 Samuel 5- 7, the idea of royalty in David and then the ark brought into a certain position in the city of David. Then we have the idea of sonship; then the position of the worshipper, sitting or tarrying before Jehovah within; all this involves the changing over from one feature of Christ, the royal feature seen in David, to the royal feature as in Solomon, in sonship. This change has to be understood, and we have to learn how to change when the time arrives in the assembly; but it has to be in spiritual power. So the Spirit of God as presented in Romans first brings in certain wealth, that is the love of God, and places it in the hearts of those who form the assembly; and then the Spirit gives a lead, as we are told in Romans 8:14:
[Page 460]
"As many as are led by the Spirit of God" -- that is where sonship appears in us -- "these are sons of God". That is the line of things I had in mind, that the saints might come to see that we are not only in fellowship, but that we are brought into an environment of great things -- royalty and what is denoted in the ark.
C.G.R. And sonship, suggested in Solomon, by the Spirit?
J.T. It is an environment of great things, and we have to move in that environment, not only intelligently, but in power, and that power is by the Spirit.
E.R.F. "The king hath brought me into his chambers" (Song of Solomon 1:4). Would that be the idea?
J.T. Quite so, it is the king who does it.
Ques. "As many as are led by the Spirit of God" Romans 8:14: would that be the change?
J.T. That is the change-over. We are earlier occupied with the Lord. The Spirit sheds abroad in our hearts the love of God. Our brother was remarking on the king bringing us into his chambers, but we have also what we are inside in the royal apartments, in Psalm 45, that is we are fit for the royal palace, "all glorious is the king's daughter within" Psalm 45:13. I believe that while we may take these thoughts in and cherish them in our minds, yet the function of the Spirit in the assembly as convened has perhaps been somewhat overlooked. He functions in two relations: in relation to the Lord in regard to royalty, according to the type in David; and then in relation to Solomon, that is, royalty in the son, the one who builds.
C.G.R. As brought into the royal apartments, into the palace, we should move with dignity.
J.T. We are there "all glorious ... within", and our "clothing is of wrought gold" Psalm 45:13. As illustrating this, we get two men alluded to in three instances, in relation to the Lord's resurrection, ascension, and transfiguration. The first is in Luke 24, where we get two men at the open sepulchre, indicating that the Lord is risen;
[Page 461]
they would impress us with regard to the realm of resurrection. Then the two in Acts 1, at the mount of Olives, would impress us with the manner of His going up -- ascension. Then on the mount of transfiguration we are told that two men appeared in glory talking with Him, but in glory, suitably robed and attired for the place; indicating what we might reach in assembly. The Spirit is necessary for all these things now. First He brings in the Lord; He operates in relation to the Lord: "no one can say, Lord Jesus, unless in the power of the Holy Spirit" (1 Corinthians 12:3). Any brother who says, "Lord Jesus", in the power of the Holy Spirit in the assembly, gives a lead. It touches our hearts as he says it by the Spirit. Then another says, "Abba, Father". Anyone saying, "Abba, Father" by the Spirit of adoption gives a lead too; he is a son, marked off as led by the Spirit. So that the procedure is not merely a matter of light, but of power.
J.S. Hence often a hymn may be given out, touching sonship but there is no thrill -- no substance.
J.T. These two men in Luke 9not only knew what to do with the light they had, but they were at home in the glory. It would seem that the two men on the mount, who are called in Luke 9:30 "two men" before we get their names mentioned, represent the heavenly saints; that is, ourselves viewed in heavenly relations; they were at home and in liberty there. Not only can the Lord speak to us, but we can speak to Him. They were speaking with Jesus, and it says they appeared in glory.
C.G.R. That suggests that we should be at home in our heavenly position and relationship.
J.T. That is the final thought. They represent the heavenly saints in liberty. So after sonship is brought in in the type in 2 Samuel 7, David goes in and sits before the Lord; he is at home and in freedom there; the word "sat" (verse 18) may be rendered "tarried", which means that he is not soon going, like someone
[Page 462]
visiting a great personage in the world and only being allowed a few minutes' audience, as is usually the case. Sonship gives us a place inside which is not limited thus.
C.G.R. Owning the Lord's authority and crying, "Abba, Father", are both by the Spirit.
J.T. Those are the two sides of the truth which I thought we might see more clearly, especially the younger brothers and sisters; so that we might understand that being in the assembly not only involves that I am breaking bread, but is a matter of power and spiritual intelligence.
W.W. The love of God shed abroad in our hearts would mean that not only would it be known in my heart, but it would be in relation to every other person who has part in this wonderful gift, would it not?
J.T. It says, "our hearts"; not indeed that the assembly is in view in Romans 5, but you can see the basis of it, the wealth that is brought in.
W.W. There is oftentimes a lack with us in working out, in relation to one another, this wonderful thought of divine wealth in the love of God given to us in the Spirit.
J.T. So that the wealth acquired in Exodus is from those whose hearts prompted them. There is no requirement of sonship in Exodus in the building of the tabernacle; not that the thing does not underlie Exodus -- it does: "Let my son go, that he may serve me" (Exodus 4:23), but what is in mind is more what is preliminary: that is what comes out in Moses as a type of the Lord. All are supposed to have wealth, but no one is asked for material save as his heart prompts him to bring it. We have wealth which lies in what the Holy Spirit sheds abroad in our hearts; every christian is in view. On the other hand when you come to the building of the temple, while all may be concerned with regard to the material for it, it is particularly the king's wealth,
[Page 463]
and the princes' wealth, that is in view; it is on another plane; sonship is in view: it is the persons.
W.C.G. "Now abide faith, hope, love; these three things; and the greater of these is love" (1 Corinthians 13:13). Do not the first few verses of Romans 5deal with these three things: justification on the principle of faith, boasting in hope, and the love of God shed abroad in our hearts?
J.T. That is right.
W.C.G. We may have faith and hope, but not much love.
J.T. Faith and hope are not material for the building; it is by love we build.
W.C.G. The greatest of these is love.
J.T. As a matter of fact it is in the comparative degree: "the greater of these is love" (1 Corinthians 13:13); the first two, faith and hope, are on the same level; love is on a level of its own. Love is the thing that abides, the tangible thing, the material. So Exodus stresses the thought of the heart; it is love that prompts the heart, meaning that I have wealth myself; I am a person in the assembly with love prompting me. We love God; we are to be in the assembly as brothers and sisters whose hearts are affected, not simply as recipients of love, but as prompted by love.
J.T-y. Every man and every woman who was willing-hearted brought gifts, and those who were wise-hearted wrought in the work.
J.T. It is the Spirit of God speaking about me, you and everybody, as to whether I am in the assembly in a living way, my heart moving in love. I am myself the material as governed by love, as having love. If I have not love I am nothing; I might as well not be there without love; but if I love, I have something.
W.W. What you have been saying about the wealth being there with the people, but only being brought by those whose hearts prompted them, gives the idea that I might have these things in the way of light, and
[Page 464]
not be holding them in power and love by the Spirit.
J.T. The apostle Paul says, "If I ... have not love, I am nothing" (1 Corinthians 13:2), which is a very sweeping statement. I had better let someone else have my seat if I have not love. It is not a question of numbers but of quality. In Israel there may have been two million people, yet the appeal was only to those whose spirits prompted them, whose hearts moved Godward. Is it not worth while to make a place for God? It is worth His while; He is willing to sacrifice in order to come down and be with us.
C.G.R. Would you say that in the power of love there would be maintained conditions suitable for Him to come in?
J.T. That is what you have in mind in coming to the assembly, that there might be a place for God.
L.D.M. In 1 Corinthians 12:13 it says: "in the power of one Spirit we have all been baptised into one body, whether Jews or Greeks, whether bondmen or free, and have all been given to drink of one Spirit"; you get two thoughts there.
J.T. Yes, the one is what is done to you -- "we have all been baptised"; it is the act of another. The one side is what is done to me; I am given my place in the body by the Spirit. It is a matter of power. Then I am given to drink into one Spirit, meaning that I am in it in a happy satisfied way, as drinking; all is a matter of the Spirit.
W.C.G. According to Romans 8:13,14, this thought of the Spirit governs all a man's movements, whether in private life or publicly, as being led of the Spirit?
J.T. Well, being led of the Spirit is not a matter of my public relations; the allusion is to Numbers 21.
W.C.G. It says, "If ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live. For as many as are led by the Spirit of God ..." Romans 8:13,14.
J.T. That means that as I apprehend the brazen
[Page 465]
serpent, there is room for the Spirit, and the leading is really spiritually in the assembly -- it is into Canaan. In the wilderness proper, the leading is by the cloud and the tabernacle. In my public movements I am regulated by where God is, by the cloud; but inwardly, from Numbers 21onwards, the tabernacle is not much in view; it is the Spirit, and the great objective is the land, entering into Canaan, which for us is realised in the assembly. I think the verse, "For as many as are led by the Spirit of God" Romans 8:14 finds its answer more in the assembly than in my outward relations, which relate to where God is known by the pillar of cloud.
Ques. How does the thought of leading fit in with the thought of headship?
J.T. It synchronises with it; so that Romans 8properly links on with Ephesians. In the type as we have it in Samuel, Jehovah says, "I will be his father": that comes out at the Lord's baptism and on the mount of transfiguration -- "and he shall be my son" (2 Samuel 7:14). Where is that answered to? Where can it be answered to more fully than in the assembly? "He shall be my son": that is what He is Godward; and the Spirit of adoption in us places us alongside of Him. What a Son the Father has in Him! The result of that communication is that David goes in and sits before the Lord: it is the inwardness of the thing. He tarries there; there is no need for him to go out. The inward thought is that the nearer I get the freer and the more at home I am. The more free I am in sonship, the more the Lord can express what He is to the Father: "he shall be to me for son" (Hebrews 1:5).
Ques. Does the tarrying suggest the liberty of the house?
J.T. Yes. "He shall be to me for son". Where could He express that more than in the assembly?
Rem. "The servant abideth not in the house for ever: but the Son abideth ever" (John 8:35).
J.T. We are free really; He sets us free.
[Page 466]
J.H.B. Will you say more about royalty as seen in David and the ark being brought to Zion?
J.T. They are preliminary to what we are speaking of now. The royalty seen in David is more a feature that marks us in relation to the ark. The ark is a mysterious thing; it is not a thing that acts of itself exactly; it is carried. I do not say that it is not presented as moving, but it is carried. Its measurements all denote that there is something more than you see; every measurement has 'a half' in it, which means that there is more than you see. The Lord says, "No man knoweth the Son but the Father" (Matthew 11:27). Now royalty in David is allied to that; and David dances before Jehovah and he set the ark in its place in the midst of the tent which David had spread for it, having brought it up to the city of David with joy (2 Samuel 6:12,17). The ark is not itself active; the activity is in David; which denotes the activity of the Spirit in us in a royal way. But then there is something more than that in the ark; it is inscrutable; there is latent power there, active when necessary, but always present. It is a very great fact that the assembly is the home of power which is always present, but in an inscrutable way. Royalty in David is more the action in us as before the ark. Then we have the desire of David after all this is finished, to build a house for Jehovah (2 Samuel 7:2). It is a good desire, but this is where the changeover comes about. David has to learn something, and we have to learn what he learnt, that is, that the building is not by royalty in David, it is in another; it is royalty still, but in sonship. That is what he has to learn, and as soon as he learns it he is restful and free; he tarries before the Lord. He "went in and sat before Jehovah" (verse 18); it is an inward thing.
Ques. Is that why it is important to follow prophetic ministry? At one moment Nathan said that David was to do all that was in his heart but then the word of the
[Page 467]
Lord comes to him in the night and he goes to David in the morning and says that another must do it.
J.T. That is right. We have to learn to be checked; that it is not all on one line in the assembly; there is another line, which you have to learn. So that in the assembly we get those who understand that when we partake of the Lord's supper and when we all drink out of the cup, the action of the Spirit would be to assure us that we are on the platform of the love of God; He would bring us on to the platform of the liberty of love (not yet sonship); for "where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty" (2 Corinthians 3:17). It is not yet the Spirit of sonship, but of the Lord. We want to get on that sure footing to which the Spirit would bring us. Sometimes a brother gives out a hymn addressed to the Father immediately after the Supper, before he gets his feet on that platform, before he sees that "where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty" 2 Corinthians 3:17. It is royalty, but in David.
P.L. "I rejoiced when they said unto me, Let us go into the house of Jehovah. Our feet shall stand within thy gates, O Jerusalem". Is that the platform? Then it says, "Whither the tribes go up": is that where they go up from? (Psalm 122:1 - 4).
J.T. That is right. It is a question of a sure footing, not only a head matter. "Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty". David later bought a large plot of ground; he bought the place to give plenty of room (1 Chronicles 21:25).
C.G.R. "Our feet shall stand" Psalm 122:2: you are there in dignity, uprightness and power.
P.L. I was thinking of the rapture; we stand together, but then we go up. Is not the attempt to go up without standing compactly together making for restraint?
J.T. That is right. All being made to drink into one Spirit implies that there is liberty and satisfaction. I believe the Lord would detain us there, and accustom
[Page 468]
us to that glory. That is a glory, certainly. We go "from glory to glory" (2 Corinthians 3:18).
W.C.G. Why is the witness of the Spirit brought in in Romans 8:16: "The Spirit itself bears witness with our spirit, that we are children of God"? Does it stand connected with the footing on which the epistle stands?
J.T. There you go on to something else, to the thought of suffering. Romans does not present the assembly; it does not take us out of the wilderness; it gives us a look into the land, but it is a wilderness position. What you have alluded to is another function of the Spirit. We say, "Abba, Father" by Him; that is properly an assembly thought, if you put it in its right setting. Then He goes on to something else; He helps to analyse the inward position. Chapter 7 helps us to analyse the working of the flesh, but the Spirit helps us to analyse between our spirit and Himself: "The Spirit itself bears witness with our spirit, that we are children of God" Romans 8:16. That leads on to another thing. We may take each principle up as given in Romans, and put it in its own setting. The spirit of adoption really belongs to the land, not the wilderness. We get foundational ideas in Romans. So if we have got our feet on the platform of liberty as accorded by the covenant in Romans 5, then we can move forward.
Ques. Would you connect the hymn that they sang, as recorded in Mark 14:26, with liberty?
J.T. It is to bring out, I believe, the mutual side. It does not say the Lord sang it; it says "When they had sung an hymn" Mark 14:26, as if He would say, 'you have been told what the cup means; now shew that you are all one'. It is the mutual side; all the saints are on that platform, so to speak.
W.W. Is that why the Lord uses such language in Luke? He says "This cup is the new covenant in my blood, which is poured out for you" (Luke 22:20). We should be concerned to see that love is poured out
[Page 469]
in relation to what we enjoy with one another. I feel myself that is where we are so small in our assembly bonds, in connection with the mighty flow of love that would devote itself to the removal of any obstacle, so that it might work.
J.T. That is how it works. There was a pause necessary. When the Lord instituted the Supper it did not take very long to pass round the emblems from one to another with the Lord and His own; but in connection with Corinth the Lord says "I have much people in this city" (Acts 18:10); and it is in connection with that thought that you have the message from heaven about the Supper; it implies that there were a good few, and in that case it takes a while for the emblems to be passed round while we sit together; that sitting together implies a platform of liberty -- "Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty" 2 Corinthians 3:17. It is a state of liberty, under authority; and the Spirit takes on a new function. There is a change-over according to the type, from David to Solomon. Nothing could be plainer in the type than that change-over. David and Nathan had a night to think it over. They both had in their minds that David should proceed on his line, that David should be the builder; but overnight there is a change-over. God impresses upon David, and on Nathan too, that there must be a son. David had not reckoned on that, and many of us do not reckon on that. We just go on on David's line, which is wonderful indeed; I would not belittle that. But God has other thoughts; and David quietly takes his place before the Lord and bows to the idea of sonship.
