L.D.M. You suggest that going along with David we do not reach sonship? The building of the house involves a universe for God for His pleasure.
Ques. Would you say that as we may have desires in relation to the house, we find that the only power to carry them out is sonship?
J.T. That is where the Spirit comes in to support
[Page 470]
us. In Galatians 4:6 the Spirit cries, "Abba, Father", Himself, but in Romans 8:15 it says, "Whereby we cry, Abba, Father". So the two sides of the Spirit's activities are clearly marked out, and I believe most of us just keep on one side -- the David side.
Ques. Would the premature movements be the result of the difference you made earlier between having light and having power? We may have the light of the position without the power that would carry us into the position.
J.T. That is where we miss it. The meetings are often somewhat without substance, because the Spirit has not given a touch or a lead. If a brother says, "Lord Jesus", by the Spirit, there is a touch there; that gives us a lead; or if he says, "Abba, Father", by the Spirit; that gives us a lead. The Spirit has a greater part in the assembly than perhaps we recognise. If He is free, He will give a lead.
W.W. Does what we are individually in the meetings have a bearing on that? What you suggest about a brother giving a lead by saying, Lord Jesus, in the power of the Spirit, raises the question whether I have anything in my mind prior to that.
J.T. Quite so; so that you are free. You do not come to the assembly with something ready; you are ready for a lead, not mentally, but as one who has substance.
Ques. When you allude to the change-over from David to Solomon, do you suggest that the thought is personified in Solomon? Does failure come in because we have nor realised the change-over from lordship to seeing our position in relation to Christ in sonship? We speak of sonship in an indefinite sort of way without seeing that sonship is realised in a definite way in Him. Is that what is in your mind?
J.T. Yes, so that the Spirit has scope in the assembly, and moves, of course, according to the constitution of it; but if He has scope there will be a lead, and the
[Page 471]
lead will be in accord with the light that governs it. So that when sonship is introduced by Jehovah to David, he bows to it, as it were; he goes in and sits down; he is now before God. That is the position we take up.
Rem. God commends him for his thought; but He had something better for him.
J.T. That is right; it is something we have to wait for -- a better, greater glory.
E.R.F. Would you say the singing of a hymn would be rather on a different platform from the singing of a psalm? Would the former require more conscious dignity?
J.T. No doubt. I think the Lord allowed the plural thought to come in there. After He spoke about the covenant then the plural comes into evidence, involving mutual movement. That is the platform. The Spirit of the Lord is there, not simply Christ; He was there, but the Spirit (typically) was present. He allowed them to move. Doubtless He took part in the hymn, but the point is that they did it. There was that spirit there which enabled them to take part by themselves. That is what the Lord loves to see.
Ques. Is what is Godward by the Spirit the great thought in the assembly, what is to be for God?
W.W. Access to the Father by one Spirit?
J.T. You get that in Ephesians: "through him", that is Christ, involving all that we have been speaking of -- the royalty in David. He is taking care of all the preliminaries, so that now we might move. It is "through him", but "by one Spirit"; the one Spirit operates in us so that there is united movement to the Father, "access ... to the Father" (Ephesians 2:18).
C.G.R. Obviously in the liberty of sonship.
J.T. Well, in the liberty of the Spirit in relation to the covenant, and then there is the change-over.
It is by the Spirit of adoption. So as soon as we are on that line, we really retard the meeting, to say nothing
[Page 472]
more, by introducing hymns or thanksgivings addressed to the Lord as such; that is where meetings are often hindered.
F.W. We might get help on this point in relation to the 'selah' or pause, might we not? Would the principle of resting in ploughing time and in harvest (Exodus 34:21) come in here? One feels one has a tendency to keep the thing going, and not get thoroughly established in one position before going on to the next.
J.T. I believe most of us live in activity; but that is not proper to the thought of the assembly, where there should be the understanding of keeping sabbath; that is, there is power in the soul by which it can rest before God, involving peace.
J.H.B. Is there not a suggestion of such a pause in 2 Samuel 6:13: "And it was so, that when they that bore the ark of the Lord had gone six paces, he sacrificed an ox and a fatted beast"?
J.T. We were dwelling on that the other night because it supports what was remarked as to the idea of a pause, or stop, accompanied by power to enjoy the position. That is what we have to learn, and that is what the idea of the sabbath teaches us. As far as we can see nearly a third of the time of Israel was taken up with keeping sabbath, if they kept them all. If you reckon the sabbatical years, and all the requirements in the way of keeping sabbath, you find that a third or a quarter of the time was occupied in that way. You say, 'Why should all that time be lost?' But it is not lost; it is love's enjoyment. We shall surely know how to be quiet in heaven in the presence of love, as "filled even to all the fulness of God" (Ephesians 3:19). It is a question of power in the soul. The time is not lost; one is taking in and enjoying.
I think it is a question with us of having to learn to be quiet. "Study to be quiet" (1 Thessalonians 4:11). That is a general direction; but you learn how to sit,
[Page 473]
tarry, before the Lord. I think the suggestion as to 'selahs' is good; 'selah' means a pause. We learn to contemplate.
Ques. Would it give the Lord an opportunity if we sit before Him?
J.T. You feel now He has us with Him. We must not live in activity in the assembly. It does not necessarily mean that we are inert. It means that there is a condition of things which the Lord can take on and use. If He is to be a Son to His Father, it means He brings all that He has and uses it in relation to His Father. Solomon says, "I was a son unto my father" (Proverbs 4:3). The assembly is a place of power and satisfied restfulness.
Rem. The disciples were there.
J.T. Yes; they were not doing anything, but they were there. So in speaking of the upper room it says, "where were staying both Peter, and John, and James" and all the others. They were staying there (Acts 1:13).
P.L. Would the absence of the sound of a hammer in the building of the temple bear upon that?
J.T. I think that; one wonders how there could be a structure like that built with no noise.
Ques. Should we wait for the Lord to introduce the thought of the Father? or are there principles which govern the position?
J.T. The Spirit may do it. He is the active One really; even the Lord's activities are by the Spirit. The Father and the Son are in heaven; the Spirit is here, and all activity is really by Him; but then He acts by Himself He keeps Himself out of view. In Colossians, He is only mentioned once. He has a great place in Ephesians, and also in Romans. It is in Ephesians that we are said to have "access by one Spirit to the Father".
-.N. Is that why you suggested just now that the Lord as moving forward from the covenant to the
[Page 474]
singing of a hymn would have the disciples move in the liberty of the Spirit?
J.T. That is what is suggested. If we can get that thought into our minds we can understand all the rest. Why did not the Lord lead the singing there? In Hebrews 2:12 (as quoted from Psalm 22), He says, "In the midst of the assembly will I sing"; but in Mark 14they sing. He had done all the rest; He had blessed the bread and broken it, He had given thanks for the cup, and now He tells them what the cup means; and the next thing is they sing a hymn.
W.C.G. Where do you connect: "In the midst of the assembly will I sing thy praises"? Hebrews 2:12.
J.T. That is properly when the Lord has us with Him. The mutual liberty is established in that singing of a hymn; it is a question of what is suitable, whether you might not give out a hymn that enlarges on the covenant, bringing in the mutual side; we are together to enlarge on the covenant. But then after sonship is introduced by the spirit of adoption, the response is to the Father; it must be so. If Christ is to be a Son unto His Father, it is in the Spirit of adoption that He has us with Him. That is the position.
J.T-y. Do you get the thought of liberty in three aspects, the liberty of love, the Spirit of the covenant, and the liberty of sonship, our hearts prompting us in the assembly in those three spheres of liberty?
J.T. That is a good classification. Our hearts prompting us would mean that we are free in the liberty of love, and I think the Lord thus has us under His hand. So, "I was a son unto my father", and again, "He shall be to me for son" -- where will this work out more than when He has us together with Him?
J.T-y. I was wondering how the Spirit of the covenant operates with us as together?
J.T. I think it produces a wealth of love which is brought in. The Spirit sheds abroad the love of God in our hearts. The assembly is to be a place of wealth.
[Page 475]
Exodus contemplates wealth from all, but from those whose hearts prompt them. 1 Chronicles contemplates wealth too, but it comes mainly from the king and the princes; it is wealth on a higher level, and that is where sonship is seen. Solomon comes in there. Everyone is dignified. That is not in Exodus, where it is under lordship. 1 Chronicles is under headship. Royalty is not only in David, but in Solomon.
C.G.R. Would you say one is more the house of God, and the other more the service of God, the incense and worship being more connected with that?
J.T. Yes. "Let my son go, that he may serve me" Exodus 4:23 comes out more in Solomon.
P.L. Do you get the personnel in John 20?
J.T. He came where they were, to persons.
P.L. There are general salutations in Romans 16, but it is only in Ephesians that Tychicus is referred to as "the beloved brother and faithful minister in the Lord" (Ephesians 6:21). Would that be more the priestly side -- the personnel in the assembly?
J.T. Just so.
J.S. Would you say that headship is not really seen in Joshua, but that we get it when we come to David?
J.T. You get hardly anything of the service of God in relation to Joshua. There is more of a link between Moses and David. In Deuteronomy you get Moses on a footing which is different from that in the earlier books; there are hardly any expressions such as "The Lord spoke unto Moses, saying", which occur so frequently in the earlier books that to count them would be impressive. In Deuteronomy we are getting on to a platform, so to speak, where we have the suggestion of headship, the nearest to it being that Moses is said to be "king in Jeshurun" (Deuteronomy 33:5), that is, he was recognised by the affections of the saints. It is not yet David. With David you scarcely ever get, 'As the Lord commanded David'; it is a question of what he did. It is headship.
[Page 476]
J.T-y. What about Joshua's concern as to the people going up to possess the land? He says, "How long are ye slack to go up to possess the land?" (Joshua 18:3). He then divides the land into seven parts which those who had not yet come into blessing should enjoy.
J.T. That is all to give us wealth for God; that is where the wealth comes from; it is acquired in the land. Numbers 15:2 says, "When ye come into the land" and goes on to speak of the offerings they would bring. The wealth in Exodus was acquired in Egypt; in 1 Chronicles it is more what is acquired in the land.
Ques. What is the thought connected with David getting so much material ready for the temple?
J.T. It was in his affliction he acquired it. You do not get anything like that in Exodus; there is no thought there of one man furnishing so much. On the side of royalty in David almost all the wealth for the temple is furnished by him; it is not the mediatorial side as in Moses, but the royal side.
Ques. If we are in the liberty of which you have been speaking we shall be intelligent as to what to do.
J.T. Of course we might be intelligent as to what to do, and yet not have the material. The great thing is to make room for the Spirit. The assembly is a place of wealth; there are great thoughts there; the question is, are we great enough to go from a great thing to a greater?
P.L. "They go from strength to strength: each one will appear before God in Zion" (Psalm 84:7).
J.T. Quite so.
E.R.F. "Who is this, she that cometh up from the wilderness like pillars of smoke" (Song of Solomon 3:6). She is seen in quiet dignity, moving up.
J.T. Then in that chapter there is movement on to collective ground, corresponding with Jerusalem. You see her coming up like pillars of smoke, with all the powders of the merchant, and going on to greater
[Page 477]
things -- to Jerusalem. The ark is eventually brought up to Jerusalem.
P.L. We are tested by the fact that many of our hymns -- and good ones too -- link up both thoughts together, and we are tested as to spiritual intelligence in the selection of a verse in such a hymn which would bear on the situation.
J.T. That is where intelligence shows itself. Hymns are sometimes designed partly to address the Lord and partly to the Father. We need to make a selection. 'Analysis' is a good word. Romans is really that. We learn the principle of analysis in relation to the flesh in chapter 7, but the epistle also enables me to analyse between my own spirit, and the Spirit of God. Mary distinguished between her soul and spirit (Luke 1:46, 47).
P.L. "When they had sung a hymn": would that suggest selection with regard to the hymn they sang?
J.T. Just so; they selected one from many.
Ques. Is it possible to obtain satisfied desire anywhere but in the assembly?
J.T. God constitutes us for company. If God intended us to be so many units we would be so accordingly; but our constitution is for the assembly, and that is where we get the thing fully, whatever it is.
[Page 478]
THE SPIRIT IN RELATION TO THE REMNANT
Haggai 2:5; Zechariah 4:1 - 14; John 14:26
I wish to speak, dear brethren, of the Spirit, the Spirit of God, in relation to the remnant of God's people. John, in his gospel, says more about the Spirit than any of the other evangelists, and whilst literally his gospel was circulated and read in early days, as the other gospels were, the fact that it came in latest of all, and the fact that it was written by one whom the Lord spoke of mysteriously (connecting him with His coming, spoken of in the last chapter of the gospel) suggests that it has a latter-day application. The great prominence given to the Spirit in it is therefore significant and interesting to us, who are in the last days. There can be no doubt about that. The last days, we are told, are perilous, perilous times shall be there. In 2 Timothy 3the apostle gives us the marks of the last days, so that by these marks we can readily tell, if we are at all spiritual, that we are in the last days, and understand their perilous character -- difficult times. Their perilous and difficult character renders necessary for us every bit of help that God may supply now, or may have supplied by forethought in the inspired record. The prominence given to the Spirit in John is therefore significant and encouraging. He is viewed in that gospel as One whose relations and work with any individual christian make him independent of the world, for He is seen in chapter 4 as a fountain of water springing up in the believer into eternal life. That is deliverance. However bad the world may be in a general way, or in any of our particular settings, there is this outlet, the power of the Spirit supporting us and lifting us consciously from the world into another realm, not exactly into heaven, but into eternal life; this has to be considered especially in its relation to the saints, to certain of the saints, for it is our privilege
[Page 479]
to enjoy eternal life in so many ways, as for instance here today. The thought is that a new order of life which renders us independent of the world is enjoyed by the Spirit. And then in chapter 14 He is seen as a personal Comforter, "another Comforter" as the Lord says. That is the Spirit here in relation to the saints collectively.
In all the epistles that may be called remnant epistles, the Spirit has a peculiar place, and I would stress that He ought ever to be before us in regard to the things the Lord gives us, the ministry from time to time. In 2 Timothy the apostle says to Timothy, "Keep, by the Holy Spirit which dwells in us, the good deposit entrusted" (2 Timothy 1:14). In that way we are enjoined to keep things not in a mental way, or in notebooks, but by the Spirit. They are thus kept in a holy way. I apprehend that is what is implied in the pound of ointment with which Mary anointed the Lord (John 12:3). There is no alabaster box; the pure nard is kept from impurity by some other way or means. It is kept, too. She kept it. She was one who loved our Lord Jesus Christ in incorruption. Then in Revelation, which is a remnant book pre-eminently, the Spirit has a great place. He is mentioned as speaking to each assembly, and everyone who has an ear is enjoined to hear what the Spirit says to the assemblies, not exactly 'to him', though that is included of course, but 'to the assemblies'. Now that speaking has peculiarly a remnant bearing, dear brethren. Seven times over in Revelation 2and 3 we have that mentioned, and it comes powerfully to every exercised soul, at all times. From the days of Ephesus to the days of Laodicea that word is intended to affect powerfully everyone who has an ear to hear. The Spirit is speaking and I am obligated to hear. There is no suggestion in these chapters that any excuse is admissible. A direct unqualified obligation to hear is put on everyone who has an ear.
Now Haggai, in the Old Testament, corresponds. It
[Page 480]
is peculiarly a remnant book. We have already today considered a remnant writer, one who wrote looking backward, the writer of the books of the Chronicles; a man, whoever he was, of profound exercise and thoughtfulness, and accuracy too, not only verbal accuracy but spiritual accuracy, which is a greater thing. Things are just where they should be in the writing. And Haggai comes in there and so does Zechariah. They are co-workers. They are men that not only ministered the word of God but could do anything that came to their hands to do -- a very important matter in a day of small things. They were prophets of God, we are told, but in the actual building of the house prophets of God helped the builders, whatever the actual work was, whether they carried water or wood (they might be hewers of wood or drawers of water), they helped. Whilst prophesying and conveying the mind of God to His people they did other things. And so they have a peculiar moral claim upon us to be heard as practical men. Practical men are in great demand today, men that can minister the word of God as taught of God and gifted of God, and who can also do what their hand finds to do that may be profitable to the saints in any way. And so the Lord took up Haggai. There is no other prophet just like him; in fact each prophet has a distinction all his own. But anyone who reads Haggai can see that he feels it. The prophecy is full of what is special in the way of dates and practical thoughts that fitted that particular time. He is a gracious man too, for he is ready to make much of the result of the word on the saints, and gives you the very day on which the thing took effect and the number of days that elapsed from the time it was heard until it took effect. He was a very interesting man in that way, and an encouraging minister and prophet. And so this verse comes in among other things of great import. "The word", says Jehovah through him, "that I covenanted with you
[Page 481]
when ye came out of Egypt, and my Spirit, remain among you" Haggai 2:5. That is, the covenant in all its fulness remained in all its blessedness. The expression here "word" suggests that it is an intelligible thought. God would stress that amongst us, that what he presents is intelligible. If I do not understand, the fault is not in the presentation of it, it is intelligible. It is comforting that the new covenant has force today and that the saints are able to take it up and speak of it with a measure of feeling, for the thing that it speaks of is known to us, not only the word, but the thing itself, that is, God's love, that is really what it speaks of, God's love in our hearts. Where should we be without the love of God? Love, we are told, never fails, but when you make that the love of God, think of what that means! It never fails. So the covenant remains and it stands by us. The result of it is that we become lovers of God, and so one of the marks of the last days is that people in general become lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God, whereas those that know the new covenant become lovers of God.
Well, that is what Haggai announces here, and it is to be received by us. I believe the Lord would lay it upon us that the word covenant, whatever the bearing of it on us, it is the thing covenanted at the beginning; that what God committed Himself to at the beginning stands. And the Spirit too, the Spirit that He gave, remains; as it says, "The word that I covenanted with you when ye came out of Egypt, and my Spirit, remain among you" Haggai 2:5. How practical it would be if each of us were to inquire now: How does this apply? 'My Spirit remains among you'. Have we not proved it here today? One can speak for oneself, that the Spirit remains now. That word "remain" signifies that there is great patience exercised. In spite of conditions He stays here. Think of the public history of christendom -- how much the blessed Spirit of God is despised and driven out and has been disregarded, and is being
[Page 482]
disregarded at the present time. Yet in spite of all these conditions, He remains. It says that He remains among you. I want to show from Zechariah how the fact becomes known to us. The prophet says that the angel awoke him and that brings up the possibility of much sleepiness even amongst those of us who have been restored outwardly. There is much too, but the fourth chapter of this prophet contemplates the divine activity, that God in His gracious patience will not suffer this sleepiness and neglect and carelessness. He says, "waked me, as a man that is wakened out of his sleep" Zechariah 4:1. And what is all this for? If God awakens me, stirs me up, it is not merely that I should be awake, but that there should be something objectively seen, something before me that I should see, something which is current that I should become acquainted with. Much is current, beloved brethren, today, that perhaps many of us here are indifferent to, and know little or nothing about. If I am characteristically an assembly person, man or woman, I will hear things. The assembly is said to have had ears at the beginning and if I am characteristically an assembly person I will hear what is current from God. What happened in Antioch in those days, it says, came to the ears of the assembly at Jerusalem and they were not indifferent ears. They immediately moved in accord with what they heard. In moving about I may say, very simply, that one finds the saints very little conversant with what is current, with what God is doing. But if we are characteristically assembly persons, we should know what God is doing. The assembly characteristically has ears for every bit of information in regard of what God is doing and, as hearing it, we should become active, at least in our prayers. In no other way, perhaps, can we serve universally than in our prayers -- prayers for all saints. Well, now Zechariah was awakened, it says, as a man out of sleep, and then the question is, What do you see? Do you see anything? It may be that what you see does not please
[Page 483]
you and yet it may be just what God is doing. If my eyesight is poor, I shall very likely have poor understanding of what God is doing, what is presented to me, and perhaps I may misconstrue what it is. Moses, the man of God who prayed, inquires for the work of God. "Let thy work", he says, "appear unto thy servants" (Psalm 90:16). That is a prayer worthy of note, that we should become cognisant of what God is doing universally and then support it sympathetically in whatever way we may. And then that our work, our own little bit, whatever it may be, may be confirmed and established by God, for if He does not establish it, it goes for nothing. Unless the Lord build a city, they labour in vain. Who can build unless God does it.
Now my point is to bring out how God graciously brings us to see that the Holy Spirit is actually here. He says He is here. He says, 'He remains' but then this chapter is to awaken us to it and to show us what results from it. So that the prophet becomes interested. All ministry, I may say, dear brethren, is largely to so interest us that we might look into things. Those who live on ministry alone, do not get on much. It is the after-searching, the following up of things that promotes growth. The prophet inquired, he acknowledged his ignorance, and he spoke reverentially to the angel. He is respectful to the person who can help him, and the angel answers him: he says, "This is the word of Jehovah unto Zerubbabel" Zechariah 4:6. That is, this word is for the man who is working, who is doing things. That is what it is for. That is, you are to know that there are men doing things, and that they are to be encouraged in what they are doing, not discouraged. Zechariah did not fail in it, as I have been saying; he helped himself, he helped to build as well as to prophesy, but the word was for Zerubbabel, and there were two persons in mind. God usually works with two persons. There are two persons in mind and the word is to bring the prophet into this, that he might encourage what is
[Page 484]
going on, not discourage it. Pulling down, you know, is the devil's work. I mean pulling down what is of God, or discrediting it in any way, or criticising it. It can stand criticism. It is sure that nothing can stand it with such resistance, as that which is of God, but the prophet Zechariah is not to be a critic. He is to encourage. He is to understand that what is going on is by the Spirit. It is not a man-made affair at all. It is by the Spirit of God and that everybody is to know that Jehovah sent the prophet and that what was being done was not by might or by power, but by God's Spirit. What a great matter that is! And how important that everyone should come into it and have part in it and promote it; if he cannot do anything with his hands, let him do it with his voice, or with his tongue in prayer, or with his purse. Whatever it may be that is needed, let him do that. The word is to Zerubbabel. Let Zerubbabel be encouraged and let it be understood that you can not overthrow Zerubbabel. You can not set aside Zerubbabel; if God puts a man forward or two men, or more, you cannot set them aside. They must be encouraged, and the man who lays the foundation will put on the top stone. You may be sure of that. That is what Zechariah is brought into. And then he says, Moreover there are seven eyes, and these are the eyes of Jehovah "which run to and fro in the whole earth" Zechariah 4:10. They bring in all the providential things of God that bear on the support of His work, and they rejoice in His work. "They shall rejoice -- even those seven" Zechariah 4:10. Let no one despise the day of small things. These are great things. It is admitted that they are not what David or Solomon had but they are universal things nevertheless and the eyes of God are running everywhere through the earth. It is a universal matter, however small it might appear to be, and those universal instrumentalities of God rejoice in what is going on. Why should not I? Why should not I be like that old sister, Anna. She rejoiced; what God was doing was
[Page 485]
everything to her, and she spoke of it, or rather she spoke of Christ. The prophet is now thoroughly interested. That is what God would do in a meeting like this: enlist the sympathies of the saints in regard of the work of God so that they might get into it themselves. The prophet, asking further questions, finally says, "What are these two olive-trees?" Zechariah 4:11. And he sees something else, and he asks another question before the other is answered. He says, "What are the two olive-branches?" Zechariah 4:12. The more you look the more you will see, dear friends. It is because you do not look that you do not see. He asks questions before the answer can come. He sees something else. What does he see? -- a branch. He has not used that word before. The branch brings the fruit nearer to me than the tree. And there are two of them, he says; there are two branches. What does that mean? Well, there is oil coming in there; there is some furnishing. Oil belongs to the ways and means of the service of God. The servants of God cannot proceed without it; if the supply is cut off the service according to God must finish. And what you get here is that there is a supply, there are pipes and the oil is running in through these pipes, and he says, "Who are these?" Well, the answer is, "These are the two sons of oil" Zechariah 4:14. These are men that are developed in this thought of oil, that is, the Spirit. They are spiritual men. They are men. That is what is needed, beloved friends, and the prophet hears the word, "that stand before the Lord of the whole earth" Zechariah 4:14. That is a great word for those who would serve. We stand usually before the few local brothers, it may be, with whom we are walking. Of course, we should be right with them, but see how great a thing it is to stand before the Lord of the whole earth! How great a thought that is! And the ministry is no less than that. If it is not that, it is nothing; one stands up in relation to the universal testimony and work of God. God has set certain in the assembly, it says. Each is
[Page 486]
a universal thought. That is what is in mind, men like that; in these remnant times, in these days of small things, there are men like that. It is not that they should be here -- they exist. It says they are there. "They stand before the Lord of the whole earth". Zechariah 4:14.
Well, I hope you will follow that part, dear brethren, and I go on now to John 14; so as to show you the direct application of the Spirit to our own times. You will remember that earlier in this chapter, as I have been already saying, the Spirit is introduced as the Comforter. He is not called the Holy Spirit, as introduced, but He is called the "Spirit of truth", "the Comforter". The Spirit of truth is a most important word, and the saints see Him and know Him and He is with them, but the world cannot see Him or know Him. As soon as the Comforter is mentioned the saints are apart. They are regarded as different from the world in regard to the Comforter. It is a Person and a Power entirely outside the knowledge of the world, outside of the cognisance of the world. They cannot see or know Him, but "ye know him, for he abides with you, and shall be in you" John 14:17. How beautiful that is! Ye see Him; He dwells in you; and He shall be in you for ever. Now all that we have in the verses that follow, up to verse 20 in that chapter, hangs on this fact, beloved brethren, that is to say, the continuance of the assembly here, and the privilege connected with it. The Lord's coming to it depends upon the great fact of the presence of the Spirit. All assembly service in the early days -- the days of the apostles -- made room for the Spirit, as we had it today. He was the medium through which Christ came in, Christ was expected to come through the early christians, and He did come in in that way, but by the Spirit. But from verse 20 onwards we have the thought of a change in these circumstances and that change implies the remnant. The Lord says, "He that has my commandments and keeps them, he it is that loves me ... and I
[Page 487]
will love him and will manifest myself to him" John 14:21. Then one says to the Lord, "Lord, how is it that thou wilt manifest thyself to us and not to the world?" John 14:22. Well, the Lord had already answered that question. Really, the world was different from them, the world could not see or know the Spirit; however trained the natural mind of man may be he is outside of the Spirit. The natural man cannot do anything about the Spirit. But the Lord answers Judas, not Iscariot, the other Judas. He says to him, "If any one love me" John 14:23. Oh, what a challenge that is, dear brethren! "If any one love me". Is it possible that anyone here does not love Christ? "If any one love me", He says. Now, when the Lord comes down to one person like that as He did in verse 21 and now in verse 23, He means remnant times. "If any one love me, he will keep my word, and my Father will love him, and we will come to him and make our abode with him". John 14:23. Now the Lord is dealing with remnant times, and you might say in the smallest way -- one person. John has in mind to set up one person here. Well, you say, you do not know how bad our city is, what conditions exist. Well I direct you to that man that the Lord left in Decapolis. I ask you to consider what Decapolis means. They had seen a wonderful miracle in that country. It is a place of ten cities; the more the cities, the greater the iniquity, the greater the wickedness, the greater the scope for the devil. And the man says to the Lord, 'I want to go with you'. And many of us would say he should go, why the place is awful! They have actually asked the Lord to leave the place, after having just performed a wonderful miracle, but the Lord says, 'No, you are not coming with me now. You are to stay here, bad as it is'. And John would fortify that place, and tell him that the Father and Son would come to him and make their abode with him. What could overthrow him? Nothing. And this leads me to speak about small meetings. They have become a sort of problem in
[Page 488]
recent times, but increase of meetings is a divine thought. The more meetings, the more the Lord's holdings. But the execution of this thought has brought about much weakness and occasion for criticism and complaint; I believe the Lord would meet this and tell us that all such criticism and complaint is really founded in unbelief. It is a question of unbelief. I am not speaking now of detail, of the working out of the thing. The Lord is able to make him stand, we are told, and the Lord is surely able to make them stand. He will support any movement in His Name with any little bit of affection for Him, and woe be to him who discredits it or would break it up! "A bruised reed shall he not break, and smoking flax shall he not quench" (Isaiah 42:3). Whatever there is, however little, support it. However little it may be, support it. The enemy is at work in discrediting the little things, the small things. We do not see it but it is true. The Lord can make them stand. It is a question of faith. The Comforter is here, the Spirit is here, and He stands by every little bit of affection for Christ and He stands by those who have affection for Christ. Let us support what is little and make the most of it. The Holy Spirit is here for that purpose and so the Lord shows here, after He has brought in this remnant, that one saint may love Jesus: "If any one love me" He says, John 14:23. You have tabernacle conditions there, conditions into which God can come and make His abode. How great that is! Then He goes on to say there are those who love Him not. "He that loves me not does not keep my words". John 14:24. The christian world is full of them. They do not love Christ and consequently do not keep His words. So He says the Father is going to send you a Comforter, and we have Him here. He is the Holy Spirit. He says, "the Comforter, the Holy Spirit". How much that is needed in a day of small things -- the Holy Spirit, the Comforter, of course, but the Holy Spirit. That is, He will maintain holiness in this condition of things.
[Page 489]
Now He says, "the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in my name" John 14:26. It is really a remnant setting -- this 26th verse. The Spirit is come from the Father in the Name of the Son and what for? To maintain all that that Name stands for, as in Matthew 18:20. The Lord says, "For where two or three are gathered together unto my name, there am I in the midst". But it is in the Spirit, it is by the Spirit He is here -- not corporeally. He is here by the Spirit. So what a support there will be, but mark you, it is the Holy Spirit here, not simply the Spirit of truth. That is, the conditions must be holy conditions, they must be in accord with God. The Spirit must see to that; He will not suffer nominal gatherings of the saints. He will not support nominal gatherings of the saints, apart from holiness. He is a Holy Spirit. And then it says, "and will bring to your remembrance all the things which I have said to you" John 14:26. That is what encourages me to believe that this has to do with the remnant. It is what has been forgotten. How much has been forgotten! Christendom has, as a system, forgotten all that Christ has said and done, but the Spirit -- how blessed it is! -- would bring to our remembrance whatever Jesus said. That is the whole truth, and what an unfolding of it we have had, dear brethren, in these last one hundred years! And it is still going on, the unfoldings of the Spirit, to the few who are holy and love Jesus, of the whole truth. Whatever Jesus said He will bring to our remembrance. That is what these meetings are largely for, that the Holy Spirit might unfold things. It has been remarked upon the change of the word, the Spirit is unfolding, not revealing. It is a time of unfolding things here, things that had been forgotten, brought to light again, brought into evidence and made intelligible. I believe the book of Deuteronomy is on that principle. Moses began to unfold this law and it is the unfolding of the first covenant. Chapter 28 brings in another covenant which was made in the plains of Moab. So,
[Page 490]
think of the wonderful service of the Spirit, the Comforter, in remnant conditions in bringing to remembrance whatever Jesus said. He teaches us too; it says, "He shall teach you all things, and will bring to your remembrance" John 14:26. It is a wonderful thing to have the power of teaching brought to bear upon us. "He shall teach you all things".
Well, that is what I had to present to you, dear brethren, and I feel the importance the more I speak of it. The Lord will not permit us to bring down the flag, as it were, to bring down the banner. No matter how feeble, the Comforter is here to comfort and to bring in all that the Lord said and to furnish us and teach us so that we might be able, as it says, "having done all things, to stand" Ephesians 6:13.
[Page 491]
THE SPIRIT'S PRESENCE FUNDAMENTAL TO CHRISTIANITY
2 Timothy 2:19; Haggai 2:5; Isaiah 59:19; Isaiah 62:6,7
I hope to speak, with the Lord's help, about what is fundamental in christianity, connecting my remarks with the presence of the Spirit who is spoken of in two of these scriptures. Then I should like to show briefly at the end how, as basic principles are recovered and put into use, they are preserved; for, if God has restored things in a functional way, it is obviously a great consideration that they should continue to function. That implies establishment which I hope to touch on in the last scripture read, God has no other thought than that there should be continuance, for which the means are furnished; these means include faithfulness in those who are enjoying the benefits of the recovery. All the scriptures, or the hortatory scriptures at least, have faithfulness in view as being essential in those who are enjoying the benefits of recovery.
Now the passage in 2 Timothy is very familiar to us and I read it because it introduces the fundamental thought in view of such days as those in which we are. This fundamental thought, of course, is prominent at the outset for the Lord had the foundation of the building in mind. It is spoken of typically in Solomon's foundation which alludes to Matthew 16. What we have in the passages read is God's foundation, but Matthew 16is Christ's foundation, Solomon's foundation, as I said. The idea in Solomon's foundation is, I apprehend, a foundation that cannot be improved upon. It is wisdom's foundation. Wisdom enters into christianity more than into any other thing or system. Not even does the physical system compare with, or equal, the wisdom that enters into christianity, which
[Page 492]
extends to ourselves in the sense that we are said to be wisdom's children. Wisdom is a feminine thought in Scripture, and as its children we are to carry on the service of our mother in that sense. Wisdom is the principal thing and inasmuch as the foundation is Solomon's, it is laid in wisdom.
The point in our verse is that it is a firm foundation. It is God's foundation but the Spirit of God is not content with saying that -- it is God's firm foundation; so no one should be timid or tread on it as if it were going to give way. He laid the foundations of the earth; the morning stars were pleased and the sons of God were pleased. "The morning stars sang together, and all the sons of God shouted for joy" (Job 38:7). Hannah in her prayer includes this thought, "For the pillars of the earth are Jehovah's, and he hath set the world upon them" (1 Samuel 2:8); and in the Psalms we have, "like the earth which he hath founded for ever" (Psalm 78:69). All that suggests firmness. Let no one, therefore, tread lightly. There are things on which you should tread lightly and carefully, but the more heavily you tread on the foundation of God the more assured you are of it. Get your feet firmly on it. "The firm foundation of God" says the apostle, "stands, having this seal" 2 Timothy 2:19. A remarkable thing that, the foundation has a seal. It carries the seal with it, a two-sided one, as we have often said. Someone says, 'Well, see how few you are'. Why are there not more christians on earth now? The fact that there are only a few as far as you can see (after all, we see little), in no sense discredits the foundation. Were there only one on it, the foundation would be what it is. It can hold one or it can hold billions of people. What about these billions, or millions, or thousands, or hundreds? "The Lord knows" 2 Timothy 2:19. It says referring to the foundation, "having this seal", as if God foresaw that there would be this questioning. Look at the foundation and see what it has. It has a seal, not simply to say that God
[Page 493]
built it, although it carries that too, but to show that it is the firm foundation of God, God coming down to that way of thinking. Of course it would be firm. If God swears, it is not that He lies if He does not swear, but it is that He assures our hearts, so if He says His foundation is firm it is to assure our hearts, for obviously it would be if it were His.
But then there is this additional thing, -- the seal, with two sides, which the foundation has. These myriads -- well, the Lord knows them. Let that cause no anxiety or uncertainty to your mind. The more of them you know the more you love them, and you will understand why the Lord knows them, why He calls them by name, and why He loves them. They are valuable in His eyes. The word is, "The Lord knows those that are his" 2 Timothy 2:19, that is, He has a claim to them and they belong to Him. That expression, "those that are his", runs along with "His own", a term of endearment. If anyone here is moving in associations displeasing to the Lord, then you are grieving his heart, He says to you, 'You are Mine, you know; I have redeemed you, I have a claim on you -- an incontestable one'. Move away from those associations that are harming you. "The Lord knows those that are his". How very comforting that is! Not merely does He know them as a matter of numbers, but He knows your down-sitting and your uprising, your associations, and where you find your enjoyment, and it will occasion Him sorrow if it is in a circle that He cannot have to say to. He knows all that is there and He says, You are Mine. "The Lord knows those that are his". The foundation carries that with it.
Then it adds on the other side, "Let every one who names the name of the Lord" (the same One who owns you) "withdraw from iniquity" 2 Timothy 2:19. Very plain speaking that, but it belongs to the foundation.
Now I want to show from Haggai how this works out. He and Zechariah are two prophets, and are
[Page 494]
certainly better than one. Any one of these prophets read by himself is good but when you see the two men together you will say they are better than one. They were unusual in the sense that they worked together; not prophesied together -- I do not say that -- but they built together. They were builders -- they understood something about a foundation. Haggai prophesied and urged forward the builders who were slacking, negligent and fearful; he urged them forward and in doing so he did not content himself with what we call ministry. He actually carried the mortar or whatever it may have been. That is what he did. He was a prophet, but he was one of those christians, or brothers, that would do whatever his hand found to do, answering to the great example of the apostle Paul. Whatever there was to be done he would do it, even to putting a stick on the fire to keep it burning. As he says, "Yourselves know that these hands have ministered to my wants, and to those who were with me" (Acts 20:34). That was the kind of workman that Paul was, and Haggai foreshadowed that kind of service. So that he knew something about building and consequently he knew something about a foundation. It is a question of the building of the house in Ezra, and for the building the foundation had to be examined and it was found to be sure. It was the real one; there was no other. I have no doubt that Haggai could have told you about it. What firmness there was there in spite of the debris that had piled up on it, -- Solomon's foundation -- which is God's foundation. Solomon's throne was really Jehovah's throne. So that you can see, dear brethren, how a remark like this in verse 5 fits in with a man s ministry of this kind. "The word that I covenanted with you when ye came out of Egypt" (meaning what He covenanted with them at Horeb long before the foundation was laid) "and my Spirit, remain among you" Haggai 2:5. "My Spirit" and "the word that I covenanted". The "word" there is very simple because it always
[Page 495]
means the impartation of the divine mind. Christ is that, fully, perfectly. In fact He is said to be a covenant to the people. He is fully and perfectly the expression of the divine mind in the covenant. Everything was there. So that we have "the word that I covenanted with you when ye came out of Egypt, and my Spirit remain" Haggai 2:5. That is, I am with you Myself, for that is what is meant. He had not left them, God's Spirit is God, God Himself, beloved brethren. The expression of His mind, so perfectly portrayed in Christ, and the Spirit remain here.
These are fundamental thoughts, thoughts that the youngest here should be able to take in, that God has plainly made His mind known in His engagement in Christ. He has made known to us what He thinks of us. If you could only spend a half-hour with God (if you will allow me to speak simply and practically), and let Him speak to you, He would fill your soul with what He thinks of you. You say, He would occupy me with my conduct. Of course He would if necessary, but that would be only so as to gain your confidence that He might fill your soul with what He thinks of you -- that He loves you. He would say, What have I not given for you? "I gave Egypt for thy ransom, Ethiopia and Seba for thee" (Isaiah 43:3). But that is nothing, I have given Jesus for you! I have given My Son for you! "Herein is love", He would remind you, "not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and sent his Son a propitiation for our sins" (1 John 4:10). That is what God would say if we would only listen to Him. He would fill our souls with what He thinks of us -- with what we are to Him.
"And they shall be unto me a peculiar treasure", says the Lord (Malachi 3:17). That is all involved in this word -- "the word that I covenanted with you"; that is, what He thinks of us, what we are in His mind, in His counsel. He has not changed one iota in regard of that. Then He adds, "and my Spirit, remain among
[Page 496]
you". He remains with us. Is it theory merely with us? No; beloved brethren. Times without number in this city and in other cities we have proved incontestably as a fact that God's Spirit remains with His people. There is no question about it. He is here today in this little place. "The word that I covenanted with you" He says, "... and my Spirit". They both remain. In other words, what I think of you, what you are to Me, what My love is for you and the power that is here to support you, remain here. Things may have broken up but these two foundational facts remain. They are facts. Let us not put them at a distance, let us not say they are theoretical. Let us say, I have proved the love of God in my own little way; I have proved the power of the Spirit in my own little way. You are setting to your seal in that way that God is true.
Everyone of us has a seal and that one thing is on it, that one thing is there: -- God is true. He loves to be trusted, and in statements like this He appeals to our hearts. Is it not really so? He would say to us. The prophets are full of this sort of thing.
Now as these great fundamental facts are in existence, I just wish to speak about the Spirit as seen in Isaiah 59. Those who recognise these great facts and are moving in the joy of them will not fail to come in for the persistent opposition of the devil. In hundreds of ways he is attacking the people of God today. He sees the brethren are making a little headway in the truth, thank God! in righteousness too, in holiness, in intelligence. A little headway, not much; I speak of it only to credit God with it, dear brethren. But however little it may be, Satan resents it and if he cannot make a frontal attack to divide us asunder, he will harass us by constant attacks, ambushes, etc. Isaiah sees the possibility of the enemy coming in like a flood. He uses water. We know how Satan, in the book of the Revelation, is seen casting a flood out after the Jewish remnant to overwhelm them. It is one of his weapons;
[Page 497]
that is to say, the control of humanity in a certain way. He would love to get control of a few of those who are walking in the truth; two or three, or however many he can get. Then he brings the wind to bear on the water and you have a flood, or the principle of a flood. He would say to some one standing for the truth, What are you going to do now? That is his way. What are you going to do with a flood? It is an overwhelming thought! But when he does that, it says, "the Spirit of Jehovah will lift up a banner against him" Isaiah 59:19. That is what He does -- not a feeble effort but a banner against him. The Spirit of God does that, dear brethren. He does it through His people of course. He is not incarnate.
It says: "Thou hast given a banner to them that fear thee" (Psalm 60:4). It is a great thing to have the fear of God before our eyes. Not slavish fear, but fear lest I might do something to dishonour His name. "For also our God is a consuming fire" (Hebrews 12:29). It is not simply "God", but "Our God is a consuming fire". Why should I not fear God? Sin in me is not any more acceptable to God than it is in the worst person in Chicago. It is more hideous in a christian if any comparison can be made. Hence to any one that feareth God He says, I will give a banner to you. "Thou hast given a banner to them that fear thee, that it may be displayed because of the truth, (Selah), That thy beloved ones may be delivered". Psalm 60:4,5. I was speaking of the Lord knowing those that are His. They are the beloved ones in that psalm. Our brethren are beloved ones whatever their association, and they are to be delivered by the setting forth of the truth in the banner.
How full and varied is this book of Isaiah. One loves to think of Isaiah; what sufferings were his! "For thus have they persecuted the prophets", says Jesus, "who were before you" (Matthew 5:12). He came in for persecution, you may be sure, but the buoyancy of his writing is most stimulating. There are many
[Page 498]
references to him by the Lord Himself in the New Testament. John also referred to him, "Esaias said again" (John 12:39). He spoke twice. What did he speak of? The glory of Jesus. He saw it -- "he saw his glory and spoke of him" (John 12:41). No one should serve, or attempt to serve, who does not see the glory. It is that which gives buoyancy and splendour to the ministry -- charged with the glory. Isaiah represents this thought as much as any writer in the Old Testament.
So here, there is the enemy coming in like a flood. Take Sennacherib; he came up to the walls with his armies. What would he not do? The Spirit of the Lord lifted up a banner through Hezekiah and those who served Hezekiah. They knew what to say. Those that went out to meet him were circumspect men but Hezekiah said to Isaiah, "lift up a prayer for the remnant that is left" (Isaiah 37:4). What a word that is for everyone that is here tonight! Lift up your prayer! Good enough to think of the beloved ones still undelivered -- indeed Isaiah tells us himself, "Yet will I gather others to him, with those of his that are gathered" (Isaiah 56:8), but Hezekiah says, "Lift up a prayer for the remnant that is left". Hezekiah takes the letter from this wicked man, Rabshakeh, the general of Sennacherib's army, and spreads it out before Jehovah.
I was reading in Isaiah 62:6 where it says, "ye that put Jehovah in remembrance". You are to remind Him of things. Do not keep silence. Keep reminding God of things. One prayer is not enough -- a thousand may not be enough. Keep reminding Him of things.
Hezekiah went in and spread the matter before Jehovah. Rabshakeh had said, Well, I will give you a few horses if you can put riders on them. That was true enough, alas! There were very few horsemen or riders inside the walls of Jerusalem. And there was a flood coming. But the Spirit of the Lord had not
[Page 499]
left; the covenant was there and He was there. What happened? "The virgin-daughter of Zion" (a daughter is a youngish thought) "despiseth thee, laugheth thee to scorn; the daughter of Jerusalem shaketh her head at thee" (Isaiah 37:22). You young sisters -- it is the daughters of Zion who have obtained their character and substance from Zion. You are to learn what that means -- daughters of Jerusalem and daughters of Zion. A daughter of Zion is just a christian, taken up sovereignly and set up in relation to God in accordance with His counsel, who is an example to others and sets forth order in this world. And they are invulnerable. She "despiseth thee, laugheth thee to scorn". The Assyrian army is smitten -- one hundred and eighty-five thousand at one stroke. That is what God does, beloved brethren! "When the adversary shall come in like a flood, the Spirit of Jehovah will lift up a banner against him" Isaiah 59:19.
Now finally in regard to the verse in Isaiah 62. These are the men, the watchmen. The building has gone up; the walls are seen to be there. The earlier chapter says: "but thou shalt call thy walls Salvation" (Isaiah 60:18). Many years ago we had a great battle here with a man who said it was heresy to say that salvation was in the assembly, in the sense in which scripture teaches. In chapter 60, the walls are called Salvation. The very idea is there. And who has not proved it? Salvation of course is in Christ -- it is there, but let us get inside the gates. Do not stay outside a moment! The gates are called Praise, and suggest the care meeting. Not only that, but the gates of Zion are loved by God more than all the habitations of Jacob. That is where the divine administration is carried on here on earth -- the walls of Salvation and the gates of Praise.
I want to show from this verse what is essential to the continuance of these things. Verse 6 says: "I have set watchmen upon thy walls, Jerusalem; all the day
[Page 500]
and all the night they shall never hold their peace" Isaiah 62:6. I have never known a time amongst the brethren when there were so many local eruptions. Things are happening here and there that are traceable directly to the enemy's workings. Young people are coming under his power, under the power of sin; they are dishonouring the Lord's name and causing sorrow amongst the brethren all over the world. And it is due to want of watchmen; not watchmen that are "dumb dogs that cannot bark" (Isaiah 56:10). What good are they if they cannot bark? That is what they are for. I believe these sorrows are largely due to lack of watchfulness, such as the elder brethren watching the younger ones, praying with them, rebuking them, "with all long-suffering and doctrine" (2 Timothy 4:2); according to God, not according to man, and in the grace and power of God checking this epidemic, as I may call it. Priestly care, of course, watchfulness surely and prayers. The Lord says, "But what I say to you, I say to all, Watch" (Mark 13:37), "abide here and watch" (Mark 14:34). It is our business to watch this young one and that young one and every one; we are keepers one of another. We are our "brother's keeper" Genesis 4:9. The leaders and elders are said to "watch over your souls as those that shall give account" (Hebrews 13:17). What we see here is, "I have set watchmen upon thy walls, Jerusalem; all the day and all the night they shall never hold their peace" Isaiah 62:6. These watchmen are apt to come in for sufferings if they are faithfully discharging their duty. It is a position that is sure to call forth resentment. They shall never hold their peace day or night. Why is that? Because of these constant uprisings of which we shall never be free. Indeed their very existence is a proof that there is something to oppose. There is something the enemy objects to. The Lord would have us take these things into account and watch.
Then we have this further word which I called your attention to in reading: "Ye that put Jehovah in remembrance", Isaiah 62:6,
[Page 501]
or as the note reads, 'think of Jehovah with loud voice'. You tell the Lord about things, not just once or twice, but until the matter is settled. Keep at it. "Keep not silence, and give him no rest, till he establish, and till he make Jerusalem a praise in the earth" Isaiah 62:7. The application of that is extremely simple. What we need is establishment in our little gatherings. Separated in this country as they are and exposed to the bitter winds in all directions, what we need is establishment. It means full growth; no longer remaining babes but becoming men. The watchmen here keep on speaking, day and night; they speak to the saints. But these remembrancers speak to God, and they give Him no rest. It is a very remarkable thing that the Spirit would write such things -- as if we could disturb His rest! But God comes down to our way of thinking. Give God no rest until a thing is settled, until there is establishment in the gatherings in the light of Christ as Head and the assembly as His body here. God is to be given no rest until there is establishment. So that the saints are going on in a positive way in the service of God instead of having constantly to be setting one another right. If we have to do that, it is proof that we are just babes. Full-grown men know what to do and they know what to say. They are balanced. We are constantly occupied in setting one another right and it is most humiliating, but God would help us to keep on praying for this brother and that brother, this sister and that sister, local or otherwise. Give Him no rest until there be establishment! May God bless the word to us!
